1 
1. Introduction 
1.1 Cross-country skiing 
1.1.1 Competition formats in cross-country skiing 
Cross-country (XC) skiing is a traditional Olympic winter sport, which has been on the 
Olympic program since the first Olympic winter games in Chamonix 1928. Since then, 
XC skiing has revolutionized extensively with average competition speeds almost 
doubled over the last five decades due to the introduction of the skating technique in 
the mid-1980s, as well as substantial improvements in skiing equipment, track 
preparations, as well as training and recovery methods [1-3]. These changes have been 
accompanied by the introduction of new events, such as the pursuit, mass-start, and 
sprint, posing different demands to XC skiers nowadays than for 50 years ago. Today, 
the Olympic events in XC skiing for women and men include distance competitions of 
10- and 15-km individual time-trials (~25-35 min), 15- and 30-km pursuits (~40-80 min),

10- and 15-km individual time-trials (~25-35 min), 15- and 30-km pursuits (~40-80 min), 
as well as 30- and 50-km mass-start competitions (~70-130 min) [4]. In addition, both 
sexes perform a distance relay (5- and 10-km for women and men, respectively) where 
each nation participate with four skiers. Moreover, the XC skiing sprint event was 
introduced during the 1990s, and has been a part of the Olympic program since Salt 
Lake City 2002, consisting of a qualifying time-trial (prologue) followed by three 
subsequent knock-out heats performed over a ~1.3-1.8-km racecourse (~3 min 
duration) [4]. Lastly, a sprint relay has later been introduced, where each nation 
competes with two skiers on the same team, performing both a qualifying and a final 
round, consisting of six laps on a sprint racecourse with similar lengths as in the normal 
sprint event [4]. Today, both the individual sprint and sprint event is a part of the

sprint event [4]. Today, both the individual sprint and sprint event is a part of the 
Olympic program together with the abovementioned distance competitions [4]. It 
should also be emphasized that the XC skiing skating technique is used in the Olympic 
winter sports, biathlon (6 events for men and women) and Nordic combined (3 events 
for men) and thus, more than 25% of the medals (including 27 gold medals) were won 
by employing XC skiing techniques during the last Winter Olympics in Beijing [5, 6].

2 
 
Figure 1. Equipment and track preparations in XC skiing has revolutionized extensively during the last 
decades, as illustrated by Magnar Estenstad in the 1950s to the left, Oddvar Brå in the 1980s, and 
Johannes Høsflot Klæbo and Didrik Tønseth during the 2021-2022 season.

1.1.2 Prevalence and popularity of cross-country skiing 
XC skiing has longstanding traditions and is particularly popular in the Scandinavian 
countries, Russia, and the northern regions of the American continent, although 
globally, the sports prevalence and popularity are relatively sparse. Therefore, the 
international Ski and Snowboard Federation (FIS) and the International Olympic 
Committee (IOC) have worked with the introduction of XC skiing and other winter 
sports to continents and countries with good climatic conditions for winter sports, 
aiming to increase winter sports participation and popularity worldwide. In this 
context, South Korea (PyeongChang) was selected as the host nation for the 2018 
Winter Olympics, and China (Beijing) for the last Winter Olympics in 2022. In fact, 
Beijing was the first host city holding both the summer Olympics (2008) and winter 
Olympics (2022). The popularity, participation, and knowledge concerning XC skiing in

Olympics (2022). The popularity, participation, and knowledge concerning XC skiing in 
China is however limited. Therefore, China developed several so-called talent transfer 
programs (also referred to as athlete transfer) within different Olympic winter sports, 
including XC skiing in their preparations towards the Beijing Olympics 2022. Talent 
3 
transfer is a process, in which athletes are transferred from their original sport to a 
new sport where they might have an opportunity to succeed, and is an alternative 
talent development model adopted by some sport government bodies [7].

1.1.3 Research in cross-country skiing 
There are longstanding traditions for researchers to work closely with coaches and 
athletes in XC skiing. Consequently, both basic studies of exercise physiology, as well 
as more applied work aiming to optimize training and recovery methods, monitor 
training adaptations, and develop XC skiing techniques have been carried out [1, 2, 8].

Pioneering work within this field was performed in the Scandinavian countries by 
acknowledged exercise physiologist such as Prof. Per-Olof Åstrand and Prof. Bengt 
Saltin, using XC skiers as a model to understand the upper limits of human physiology 
[9]. Their initial work has further led to a considerably high number of scientific 
publications in XC skiing over the last decades [2] and thus, increased our 
understanding of the competitive demands, as well as the optimal training methods 
and technical patterns in XC skiing [1, 2, 8]. Particularly in the Scandinavian countries, 
the close collaboration between researchers and practitioners in XC skiing have likely 
contributed to a training philosophy build on a strong theoretical framework.

Therefore, it may be argued that the combination of retrospective training analyses of 
world-class XC skiers practice together with more experimental designs have led to a 
well-developed theoretical framework of endurance training in XC skiing (i.e. state-of-
the-art training methods). These training methods are described in a review on the 
competitive demands and training characteristics in XC skiing by Sandbakk and 
Holmberg 2017 [2].

1.2 The physiological demands of cross-country skiing 
XC skiing is clearly among the most demanding endurance sports and involves 
competitions performed across varying terrain while changing between the different 
sub-techniques of the classical and skating technique. Consequently, XC skiing involves 
4 
large fluctuations in both speed, work rate, and metabolic intensity while combining 
upper- and lower-body work to different extent [1, 2, 10]. Moreover, XC skiing 
competitions include different environmental conditions, requiring XC skiers to adapt 
their speed and pacing strategies to different snow conditions and competition 
altitudes (ranging from 0 to 1800 m) [4, 6, 11, 12]. Moreover, the equipment of XC 
skiers must be optimally adopted to both the XC skiers’ anthropometrics and snow 
conditions [2]. Since 5 out of 6 Olympic events in XC skiing today involve “head-to-
head” competitions, tactical expertise and final sprint abilities are crucial performance

head” competitions, tactical expertise and final sprint abilities are crucial performance 
determinants. Taken together, XC skiing requires both high aerobic and anaerobic 
energy turnover rates, strength, and speed, as well as technical and tactical expertise 
[1, 2, 10, 13].

1.2.1 Energy demands, sub-techniques, and pacing strategies  
Endurance performance is normally determined by the athlete’s VO2 achieved during 
the competition (i.e. performance VO2) combined with performance O2-deficit and 
work economy/efficiency [14]. However, the physiological demands of XC skiing are 
unique compared to many endurance sports due to the constant fluctuations in speed 
and metabolic intensity during both training and competitions [10, 15-20]. XC skiing 
racecourses are designed to include approximately one-third uphill, one-third flat, and 
one-third downhill terrain [4]. Here, around 50% of the racing time is spent uphill, 
whereas ~35% and ~15% is spent in flat and downhill terrain, respectively. However, 
XC skiers typically spend only between ~10 to 70 sec per terrain section although longer 
times (~90-150 sec) may occur in some racecourses [10, 15, 17]. Consequently, XC 
skiers must master different sub-techniques, select the most optimal sub-technique,

skiers must master different sub-techniques, select the most optimal sub-technique, 
and effectively change between different sub-techniques at various speeds (5-70 km·h-
1) and inclines (-20% to +20% gradients) [2, 10]. In fact, it has been demonstrated that 
XC skiers perform ~25 sub-technique transitions per km throughout the racecourse 
[21-23]. Here, the most common sub-techniques (also referred to as gears) are G2 (V1), 
G3 (V2), and G4 (V2a) in the skating technique, and diagonal (DIA), double-poling with 
5 
kick (DPK), and double-poling (DP) in the classical technique. In addition, the tuck 
position is used during downhill terrain sections at high speeds in both techniques.

The uphill sections are regarded as the most performance-differentiating sections in 
XC skiing, although better performing skiers are typically faster in all sections compared 
to their lower-performing counterparts [20, 21, 24, 25]. However, it has also been 
suggested that the uphill sections are more performance-differentiating among female 
XC skiers and that performance in flat and varied terrain are more differentiating 
among male XC skiers [26, 27]. In the uphill sections, XC skiers increase both work rate 
and metabolic intensity, whereas the subsequent downhill sections are primarily used 
for recovery and the metabolic intensity is reduced (see Figure 2 for illustration). These 
interval-based fluctuations in speed across varying terrain sections is referred to as 
micro-pacing, although on a macro-level (lap-to-lap basis), XC skiers tend to employ a 
positive pacing strategy, with gradual reductions in speed throughout the competition

positive pacing strategy, with gradual reductions in speed throughout the competition 
[12, 20, 22, 24, 25, 28]. However, the best performing skiers typically maintain speed 
better (more even pacing strategy) in comparison to their lower-performing peers, as 
consistent with other endurance sports [12, 28, 29]. The requirements for higher 
intensity in uphill terrain in XC skiing drives metabolic demands considerably above 
those required to elicit the maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max). This includes work rates 
as high as ~40% and ~15-20% above VO2max during the uphill sections in sprint and 
distance XC skiing, receptively [15, 17, 30-33]. Therefore, XC skiing requires high 
anaerobic energy turnover rates (i.e. maximal accumulated oxygen deficit [ΣO2-deficit]) 
but more importantly, the ability to recover during downhill sections and thereby 
reproduce anaerobic energy turnover [10, 18]. However, the average aerobic energy

reproduce anaerobic energy turnover [10, 18]. However, the average aerobic energy 
contribution in sprint (~70-75%) and distance XC skiing (~85-95%) is comparable to the 
corresponding values for other endurance sports with similar durations [10, 14, 34, 35].

Accordingly, a high aerobic energy turnover rate together with an efficient skiing 
technique are clearly the most important determinants of performance in XC skiing [1, 
2, 8].

6 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Figure 2. Elevation profile in a 4.5-km cross-country skiing competition and associated changes in 
speed, estimated power output and oxygen demand (green, aerobic energy turnover; red, anaerobic 
energy turnover). Used with permission from Sandbakk et al [6].

1.2.2 Energy turnover capacities 
Several studies have demonstrated that XC skiers are among the endurance athletes 
with the highest VO2max values ever reported in the scientific literature. These values 
are reported to be 6.0-6.5 and 4.0-4.5 L·min-1, corresponding to 80-90 and 70-80 mL·kg-
1·min-1 for male and female XC skiers, respectively [36-41]. Moreover, ventilation rates 
>250 L·min-1, cardiac outputs >40 L·min-1, stroke volumes >200 ml, blood volumes >9 
L, and hemoglobin mass (Hbmass) values >1100 g are all reported in elite male XC skiers 
[8, 36]. In addition to high VO2max values, the technically and physiologically demanding 
changes between different sub-techniques in XC skiing requires a high development of 
peak oxygen uptakes (VO2peak) within all the main sub-techniques of the classical and 
7 
skating technique [2, 39]. Previous studies have shown that XC skiers typically reach 
VO2peak values ~3% lower in the skating sub-techniques (G2 and G3) and ~10% lower in

VO2peak values ~3% lower in the skating sub-techniques (G2 and G3) and ~10% lower in 
the classical DP sub-technique compared to running [38, 39, 42]. However, the highest 
VO2max values (~3% higher than running) are typically obtained in the classical DIA sub-
technique where both the upper- and lower-body are involved in producing work [36, 
43]. Accordingly, XC skiers must target the development of high VO2peak/VO2max ratios, 
which might be more relevant in elite XC skiers, where further improvements in VO2max 
may be limited [10]. Together with these maximal aerobic turnover rates, XC skiers 
must develop high fractional utilizations of VO2max and VO2peak (i.e. performance VO2).

In many endurance sports, the anaerobic threshold (maximal lactate steady state 
(MLSS) or critical speed/power) is considered an indirect measure of the athlete’s 
fractional utilization during competitions [14, 44, 45], although it is not a valid measure 
of the fractional utilization in XC skiing due to the interval-based fluctuations in 
metabolic intensity [2, 45]. Such threshold-derived measures also differ depending on 
the extent to which the upper- and lower-body are involved in producing work [46], 
increasing the complexity of such measures in XC skiing compared to other endurance 
sports. However, such threshold concepts can be used as valuable tools to monitor 
training adaptations across different training cycles in XC skiers. Moreover, the 
fluctuating intensity during XC skiing competitions places great demands on O2-kinetics 
[2]. Both rapid O2-delivery and sufficient O2-extraction to maintain homeostasis of the

[2]. Both rapid O2-delivery and sufficient O2-extraction to maintain homeostasis of the 
muscle milieu is however challenging with the fluctuating metabolic intensity and 
changing sub-techniques during competitions [2, 8]  Therefore, O2-kinetics is highly 
related to the fractional utilization of VO2max. in XC skiing [2]. As mentioned above, a 
high anaerobic energy turnover rate is also an important performance determinant in 
XC skiing [2, 8] and particularly in sprint XC skiing [33]. However, it is not a high ΣO2-
defcit per se that is most important, but rather the ability to repeatedly perform and 
recover from work rates above VO2max/VO2peak during the uphill sections [10, 15, 18, 
47].

8 
1.2.3 Work economy and efficiency 
Furthermore, XC skiers must effectively convert metabolic energy into external work 
rate and speed. Hence, the role of both work economy and gross efficiency as 
performance determinants have previously been investigated in XC skiing [48-54].

Taken together, studies on work economy indicate differences in oxygen cost between 
XC skiers of different performance levels using double-poling ergometry or treadmill 
roller-skiing at similar submaximal work rates/speeds [48-51]. However, more recent 
development of customized ski-specific treadmills has provided the opportunity to 
investigate mechanical efficiency (e.g. gross efficiency) in XC skiing due to more 
accurate calculations of work rate [53]. Here, gross efficiency is defined as the ratio of 
work generated to the total energy expended (metabolic rate) [53]. Although there are 
conflicting viewpoints, previous studies have shown gross efficiency to be correlated 
with performance in both sprint and distance XC skiing [52-56]. In this context, better 
performing skiers often demonstrate a skiing technique with longer cycle lengths and 
lower cycle rates, indicating better technique-specific propulsion that could possibly

lower cycle rates, indicating better technique-specific propulsion that could possibly 
explain variations in work economy and efficiency between skiers of different 
performance levels [53, 56]. Here, an adequate level of both upper- and lower-body 
strength and power is needed to produce and transfer forces efficiently. Longer cycle 
lengths and higher efficiency has previously been related to maximal strength and 
power in movement specific exercises [57-59], as well as more effective leg and pole 
push-offs among XC skiers [53, 58, 60].

1.3 Endurance training 
Endurance training involves manipulation of training intensity, volume, frequency, and 
mode, with the goal of maximizing adaptive responses and performance development, 
while maintaining good health and mitigating side-effects [61-65]. Accordingly, the 
organization and optimization of endurance training, and in particular training volume, 
intensity distribution, and periodization models have been debated among sports 
scientists and practitioners over several decades [61-65].

9 
1.3.1 Training volume 
Retrospective training analyses have shown that successful elite endurance athletes 
perform high annual training volumes, varying from ~500-600 hours in middle- and 
long-distance runners [5, 66-69] and orienteers [70] up to ~1000-1300 hours in 
swimmers [71], cyclists [72-74], and triathletes [75]. The training volumes of XC skiers 
[2, 39, 56, 76-78], biathletes [78, 79], and speed skaters [80] are reported to be 
somewhat in between these volumes, typically ranging from ~700-900 hours annually.

Clearly, high training volumes are needed for success in endurance sports, with the 
large variations between endurance sports possibly explained by differences in 
neuromuscular load, muscle contraction cycles, and the ability to change between 
different training modes (cross-training), which all influences the overall training 
tolerance [81]. It should also be noted that relatively large between-athlete variations 
in training volume within different endurance sports are evident [81].

1.3.2 Training intensity distribution  
Although the volume and frequency of endurance training are rather straightforward 
to quantity, the intensity is more complex. Consequently, training intensity is typically 
quantified using different intensity zones based on measures of external (e.g. speed 
and power output) and/or internal load (e.g. heart rate [HR], blood lactate 
concentrations [La−], gas exchange, and rating of perceived exertion). While several 
intensity zones have been suggested and employed by different sport government 
bodies [82], a three-zone scale related to the first and second ventilatory threshold 
concept (Figure 3) are commonly used in the scientific literature: low-intensity training 
(LIT, <2 mmol·L-1 [La−] and 60-82% of maximal heart rate [HRmax]), moderate-intensity 
training (MIT, 2-4 mmol·L-1  [La−] and 82-87% of HRmax) and high-intensity training (HIT, 
>4 mmol·L-1  [La−] and >87% of HRmax) [62, 64, 82]. However, different intensity zones

>4 mmol·L-1  [La−] and >87% of HRmax) [62, 64, 82]. However, different intensity zones 
as well as different methods of quantifying endurance training (e.g. time in zone vs.

session goal approach) should be taken into consideration while interpreting data from 
retrospective training analyses [83]. In their training process, most elite endurance 
10 
athletes adopt a model consisting of high volumes of LIT combined with low- to 
moderate amounts of MIT and/or HIT [61, 62, 64]. Therefore, specific training intensity 
distribution models such as pyramidal (LIT>MIT>HIT), polarized (LIT>HIT>MIT), and 
threshold (MIT>LIT>HIT) are most used among endurance athletes. However, the exact 
training intensity distribution seem to depend on the sport-specific demands, 
individual requirements, as well as the phase of the annual training cycle [61, 64, 81].

Accordingly, there are likely no optimal training intensity distribution that can be 
adopted both within and between different endurance sports, which has recently been 
addressed in two counterpoints on the polarized intensity distribution model [84, 85].

In this context, endurance athletes often progress their overall training load 
throughout the preparation period, which can be achieved either by increased volume 
LIT and/or volume MIT/HIT. High volumes of LIT is often seen as an important stimulus 
for inducing peripheral adaptations such as increased mitochondrial biogenesis and 
capillarization of the skeletal muscle [86, 87], whereas central adaptations such as 
increased stroke volume of the heart, leading to improved VO2max, are regarded as 
more responsive to intensification of the overall training stimulus [86-88]. However, 
this dichotomous viewpoint is likely exaggerated as both LIT and HIT have many shared 
molecular pathways (e.g. upregulating PGC-1α) and therefore elicits complex and 
integrated adaptive signaling [61, 86]. The training process of endurance athletes 
including questions on training intensity is always about prioritization (cost-benefits of

including questions on training intensity is always about prioritization (cost-benefits of 
different training), in which successful athletes are able to maximize adaptive 
responses while mitigating side-effects such as fatigue, under fueling, non-functional 
overreaching, and overtraining syndrome [61, 89].

11

1.3.3 Experimental training studies and methodological considerations 
The abovementioned training volumes and intensity distributions are mostly based on 
retrospective analyses of elite endurance athletes training diaries, although several 
short-term experimental studies (e.g. 4-12-week interventions) have been carried out 
to further increase or understanding of the effects of different endurance training and 
its corresponding adaptive mechanisms. In this context, valid methods for matching of 
training intensities and loads are required. However, most previous experimental 
studies investigating the effects of different training intensities have used methods in 
which different intensities/loads have been matched for total work or oxygen 
consumption (iso-energetic methods). Taken together, these studies emphasize the 
superiority of HIT for maximizing physiological adaptations and endurance 
performance [88, 90, 91]. However, such studies can be seen as artificial and not

performance [88, 90, 91]. However, such studies can be seen as artificial and not 
realistic from the perspective of which endurance athletes train and perceive stress 
from different endurance training intensities [64]. Endurance athletes can perform 
more work, both energetically and in terms of total work with LIT compared to HIT [92].

12 
Accordingly, high volumes of LIT may be advantageous for accumulating high training 
volumes and optimizing adaptative responses at a tolerable level of stress, despite 
most experimental evidence suggesting superior adaptations by intensification and a 
more polarized intensity distribution [93]. Moreover, most previous training 
intervention studies are often limited by short intervention periods, and therefore, we 
do not know how the effects of typical short-term intensification studies would 
influence subsequent training periods or if their effectiveness would be maintained 
over longer time spans. Hence, knowledge regarding the more subsequent effects of 
training interventions and particularly intensification studies in endurance athletes are 
currently lacking.

1.3.4 Training periodization models 
The structure and organization of endurance training is often referred to as training 
periodization [94, 95], which involves different ordering of the training stimulus within 
micro- (2-7 days), meso- (3-6 weeks), and macrocycles (6-12 months). Macrocycles can 
further be structured into general preparation period, specific preparation period and 
competition period [94, 95]. The term traditional periodization emphasizes high 
training volumes in the general preparation period, with a change towards more focus 
on intensity, reduced volume, and more specific training in the specific preparation 
period [94-96]. This model has been adopted by many endurance athletes, 
demonstrating high volumes of LIT combined with low-to-moderate amounts of MIT 
and/or HIT in the general preparation period, whereas the specific and/or competition 
period is often characterized by reduced volume and more intensified training (i.e.

polarization) This periodization model is also supported by a recent training 
intervention study supporting the benefits of a pyramidal followed by a polarized 
intensity distribution over polarized followed by pyramidal or performing polarized or 
a pyramidal intensity distribution alone during a 12-week intervention in trained 
runners [97]. Coincided by the abovementioned changes in training intensity 
distribution, elite endurance athletes often change their HIT stimulus from the general 
13 
preparation to the specific preparation period [70, 98, 99]. This includes a higher 
frequency of HIT sessions, often performed at a higher intensity closer to competition 
speeds (i.e. increased specificity) with reduced duration. Anecdotally, this may provide 
an «aerobic base» in the general preparation period prior to targeting more HIT and 
speed adaptations in the specific preparation period, with the intention of achieving

speed adaptations in the specific preparation period, with the intention of achieving 
peak performance in the competition period. However, the literature on the effects of 
different training intensity periodization models in endurance athletes are relatively 
sparse.

1.3.5 Individual training responses 
The inter-individual responses to endurance training are determined by a complex 
interplay between training load (i.e. volume and intensity) and the subsequent 
recovery (e.g. sleep, nutrition, and non-training stressors), in which pre-training status 
and genetics plays additional roles [100]. Accordingly, training responses to 
standardized training prescriptions demonstrates large variations, with individuals 
represented in both ends of the response range, a phenomenon often referred to as 
“high- and low-responders” [100]. In fact, it has been suggested that as many as 20% 
demonstrates no physiological adaptations (e.g. increased VO2max) to different 
endurance training programs (i.e. non-responders) [101, 102]. Contrary, it has been 
argued that individual adjustments of training load (particularly through increased 
loads) would reduce the number of low- and non-responders to endurance training,

loads) would reduce the number of low- and non-responders to endurance training, 
which often is a limitation in typical training interventions using similar load 
prescriptions for all participants. Such methods of prescribing training load is 
somewhat artificial and considerably different from how coaches actually program and 
prescribe endurance training [102]. Consequently, individual adjustments of load are 
likely required to optimize adaptive responses and avoid negative outcomes [103, 104].

Classification of different responders to endurance training has also been criticized for 
the influence of confounding factors such as technical measurement error and 
between-athlete variation (e.g. test-retest reliability) which should be considered in 
14 
the interpretation of different responders to endurance training. Altogether, better 
understanding of underlying factors related to individual differences in response to 
endurance training is of uttermost importance [100, 103], and there is currently limited 
evidence on individual responses to endurance training programs using more 
ecological valid design including individual prescriptions of training load.

1.4 The training characteristics of elite cross-country skiers 
The training of XC skiers targets a concurrent development of the abovementioned 
performance determinants, especially programmed for long-term development of high 
aerobic energy turnover rates and skiing efficiency [2]. These training methods have 
led to the development of extraordinary high VO2max/VO2peak values among XC skiers 
possibly explained by the use of different training modes and the combination of 
upper-, lower- and whole-body work [36-41]. Retrospective training analyses have 
demonstrated that the annual training volumes of world-class XC skiers (~750-950 
hours) consists of ~90% endurance training, and ~10% strength and speed training [2, 
39, 56, 76-78]. Interestingly, higher annual training volumes (~20%) have been found 
among world-class compared to national-level skiers [39, 56]. Approximately ~60% of 
the annual training volume is performed during the preparation period (May to

the annual training volume is performed during the preparation period (May to 
October) and the remaining ~40% in the competition period (November to April). The 
endurance training is distributed as ~90% LIT, ~4-5% MIT, and ~5-8% HIT across the 
annual training cycle, although a change from a high-volume LIT and/or pyramidal 
intensity distribution in the preparation period towards a more polarized distribution 
in the competition period is typically observed [2, 76, 78]. However, it is important to 
note that these intensity distributions are averages values, and that both scientific and 
anecdotal evidence suggests that XC skiers balance training volume and intensity 
somewhat different [77, 105, 106]. For example, different emphasize on HIT has been 
adopted by elite XC skiers, with the most successful female XC skier of all time, 
employing two different intensity distributions and periodization models during her

employing two different intensity distributions and periodization models during her 
career (i.e. extensive HIT-block periodization vs. more LIT focus and traditional 
15 
periodization) [77]. In the seasons prioritizing HIT and block-periodization, the 
distribution of LIT/MIT/HIT was 88/1/11 with the corresponding values being 92/4/4% 
in the seasons prioritizing LIT and more traditional periodization. Despite different 
emphasize on LIT vs. HIT, the overall training loads were similar between the two 
seasons. A follow-up study also presented data on the physiological responses to 
extensive HIT using different exercise modes over three annual cycles in 14 world-class 
female XC skiers [105]. Altogether, these retrospective studies suggest different 
emphasize of endurance training intensities in XC skiers and there is an ongoing 
discussion on how training volume and intensity should be progressed throughout the

discussion on how training volume and intensity should be progressed throughout the 
preparation period to optimize performance development. Moreover, XC skiers 
typically perform 50-60% of their training in specific exercise modes (i.e. roller skiing 
and skiing) during the preparation period, whereas the remaining is mainly performed 
as running and/or running with poles. The running is often performed in varied terrain 
and soft surfaces such as mountains and marshland. During the competition period, 
most of the endurance training is performed as skiing combined with only small 
amounts of running [2, 76, 78]. Alternations between several training modes (general 
and sport-specific) involving different loading of the upper- and lower-body might 
explain the relatively high training volumes observed in XC skiers. This is comparable 
to e.g. triathlon and likely increases the overall tolerance for high training loads

to e.g. triathlon and likely increases the overall tolerance for high training loads 
compared to e.g. middle- and long-distance running, which are associated with higher 
neuromuscular loads [81]. The introduction of new events in XC skiing, such as the 
pursuit, mass-start, and sprint events has increased the demand for speed and strength 
training. Consequently, world-class XC skiers perform ~2% speed training annually, 
either as single sessions or integrated into different LIT sessions. Moreover, XC skiers 
perform ~8% strength training including both core/stabilization exercises, and more 
strength- and power-oriented exercises. However, the extent to which XC skiers 
prioritize strength/power training seem to vary extensively between XC skiers and are 
likely more prioritized in sprint than distance XC skiers. This is also supported by 
experimental studies investigating the effects of heavy strength training on XC skiing 
16

experimental studies investigating the effects of heavy strength training on XC skiing 
16 
performance, demonstrating inconsistent findings [48, 107-109]. Altogether, the 
training puzzle of XC skiers involves sophisticated manipulation of training forms 
(endurance, strength, and speed), intensity (LIT, MIT, and HIT), and mode (sport-
specific and general). Although a significant number of studies have retrospectively 
analyzed the training characteristics of successful XC skiers, there is currently a lack of 
intervention studies investigating the actual effects of different load progression, 
intensity distributions, and periodization models in XC skiing. This is particularly 
important considering the fact that retrospective training studies may be limited by 
confirmation bias and selection bias (e.g. survivorship bias) ignoring the fact that more 
unsuccessful athletes likely also performed comparable training volumes and intensity

unsuccessful athletes likely also performed comparable training volumes and intensity 
distributions without the same level of success.

1.5 Talent transfer 
Over the last decades, practitioners and researchers have searched for optimal 
methods to optimize performance development in sports. In this context, an 
alternative development model adopted by some sport government bodies have been 
talent transfer (also referred to as athlete transfer) [7, 110]. Talent transfer can be 
defined as a process in which athletes are transferred from their original sport (i.e.

donor sport) to a new sport (i.e. transfer sport). The overall idea of talent transfer is to 
recruit athletes who have shown high-performance levels in a sport, both through 
investment in time and effort, without taking the last step to an elite level.

Consequently, the athletes are provided the opportunity to transfer to a new sport 
where they might have better potential for success. Such talent transfer initiatives have 
been conducted in different sports over the last decades with the most recent 
examples being Great Britain prior to the London Olympics in 2012 [7], and China, both 
prior to the Beijing summer Olympics 2008, and the Beijing winter Olympics 2022.

Investing in such talent transfer initiatives could increase the possibility to perform in 
sports where nations historically have been less successful and are therefore mostly 
used by host nations in connection with the Olympics. However, a recent systematic 
17 
review showed that the available evidence on talent transfer initiatives is limited, 
concluding that similarities between the original and the new sport were clearly 
associated with the highest success rates [110]. Therefore, a crucial part of talent 
transfer initiatives is to understand the connection between the original sport and the 
new sport, as well as finding the appropriate selection criteria, where previous studies 
have been criticized for using too narrow inclusion criteria, focusing mainly on physical 
and anthropometric factors [111]. Altogether, transfer of individual athletes [112] and 
groups [113, 114] to new sports are commonly used in sports practice, although such

groups [113, 114] to new sports are commonly used in sports practice, although such 
initiatives in endurance sports and particularly winter sports such as XC skiing have not 
previously been explored in the scientific literature. In addition, an individual’s 
physiological and anthropometrical potential for successful transfer to a new sport and 
the underlying mechanisms explaining the development are currently unexplored 
[110]. An interesting question in this context is also the development of general vs.

sport-specific performance and physiological indices following talent transfer. For 
example, it would be interesting to understand how athletes originating from other 
endurance sports would progress their VO2max/VO2peak values or if sport-specific 
performance development would be explained by the improvements in other 
performance-determining variables such as strength/power, technique, and efficiency.

As aforementioned, China developed several talent-transfer programs in their 
preparation towards the Beijing 2022 winter Olympics. Here, athletes from different 
summer sports (e.g. running, rowing, and kayaking) were transferred to XC skiing by 
employing state-of-the-art training methods (as described in detail above) [2].

1.6 Motivation for the present dissertation  
The motivation for the present dissertation was to increase our understanding of both 
the short-term and more subsequent effects of increased LIT vs. HIT on performance 
and physiological adaptations during the preparation period in junior XC skiers, as well 
as the influence of adopting state-of-the-art training methods to endurance athletes 
originating from other sports while transferring to XC skiing. Within the theoretical 
18 
framework of endurance training in XC skiing, more experimental evidence through 
training interventions is clearly needed to further understand optimal manipulation of 
training volume and intensity on adaptive responses and performance development.

Specifically, both the scientific literature and anecdotal evidence suggest the use of 
different load progression, training intensity distributions and periodization models.

Thus, leading to an ongoing discussion among both researchers and practitioners 
within this field concerning “the optimal endurance training”. Additionally, most 
available studies on endurance training manipulation are limited by artificial matching 
of training intensity and/or lack of data on the intervention’s effectiveness over longer 
time spans (i.e. subsequent effects). Moreover, the process of adopting the theoretical 
framework of endurance training in XC skiing to other endurance athletes while aiming 
for success in XC skiing was motivated upon the fact that there currently exist no 
scientific data on endurance athletes transferring between different sports during their 
career. Here, it would also be interesting to understand how these athletes would 
develop their maximal aerobic turnover rates, in addition to improving their technique, 
strength, and efficiency, while transferring to XC skiing and adopting these training

strength, and efficiency, while transferring to XC skiing and adopting these training 
methods. This process was initiated through a sport collaboration between Norway 
and China aiming to increase the popularity and participation of XC skiing worldwide.

19 
2. Purposes 
Overall purpose study I-II 
To investigate both the short-term and more subsequent effects of increased low- vs.

high-intensity training on performance and physiological adaptations during the 
preparation period in junior cross-country skiers.

Study I:  
To compare the effects of increased load of low- vs. high-intensity 
endurance training on performance and physiological adaptations in 
cross-country skiers.

Study II:  
To investigate how the effects of increased low- vs. high-intensity 
endurance training in an 8-week intervention influences the subsequent 
development of performance and physiological indices in cross-country 
skiers.

Overall purpose study III-IV 
To investigate the influence of adopting state-of-the-art training methods in cross-
country skiing to endurance athletes originating from other sports in a so-called talent 
transfer program.

Study III:  
To examine the development of performance, physiological, and 
technical indices as well as the effect of sport background among 
runners, kayakers, and rowers when transferred to cross-country skiing 
over a 6-month training period.

Study IV:  
To compare high- and low-responders following a 6-month training 
period in endurance athletes transferring to cross-country skiing by using 
a multidisciplinary approach.

3. Scientific theory 
The present dissertation exemplifies applied research focusing on the field of 
professional practice. Consequently, optimal interaction between research and 
practice has been a crucial part of the work constituting this dissertation. To improve 
the interaction between research and practice, understanding the role of tacit 
knowledge has been of relevance. Tacit knowledge is an important feature of 
professional practice and describes the knowledge gained through practice and 
represents knowledge that cannot directly be explained by words (i.e. articulated) 
[115]. The fact that much knowledge is silent means that it cannot be expressed 
explicitly but is more personal and anchored in elements such as intuition, experience, 
ideas, values, and emotions [115]. Tacit knowledge can also be described as non-
articulated knowledge although sometimes, different forms of knowledge are indeed

articulated knowledge although sometimes, different forms of knowledge are indeed 
articulated. While applied research involves important questions relevant for the field 
of practice, there will always be elements of practice that cannot be articulated and 
thus often are easier to demonstrate. Tacit knowledge can also be described as 
experiential competence, which can be knowledge difficult to transfer to others [115].

For example, this can be the coach who based on purely observing the athlete on a 
daily basis are able to do optimal decision-making concerning the training process (e.g.

adjustments of training load) or feedback on the athletes technique. Such examples of 
tacit knowledge involve complex situations consisting of many elements, requiring the 
ability to navigate, and understand the totality of the situation. In (elite) sports, it is 
often difficult to articulate all the knowledge and experience practitioners gain in the 
process of achieving world-class performances. Articulation of such knowledge can for 
example be retrospective analyses of successful athletes training diaries and case 
studies on the physiological profile of elite and world-class athletes. While such studies 
provide valuable insights into the training characteristics of elite to world-class 
athletes, they are also limited by factors such as selection bias, ignoring the fact that 
many athletes probably followed much of the same training without achieving the 
same success [84]. Although most of this dissertation concerns quantitative data within 
22

same success [84]. Although most of this dissertation concerns quantitative data within 
22 
the field of exercise physiology, qualitative assessments were additionally included in 
parts of the methodology (i.e. mixed-design) to gain complementary insights into the 
training and recovery process of athletes. Tacit knowledge is often developed through 
close relationships and observations between athletes and coaches, and by athletes 
observing the behavior of other athletes in a process where practical knowledge is 
translated into practice. For example, an athlete can gain tacit knowledge by purely 
observing the coach or another athlete perform their skills ("model learning").

Important tools in this process are observation, visualization, and imitation. "Model 
learning" is a central part of (elite) sports and involves not only observation and 
imitation of technique, but all aspects of the training process (e.g. training content and 
quality). It may be argued that factors such as training quality explains much of the 
variance between successful and less successful athletes although similar training is 
prescribed and carried out. However, such factors are often more difficult to articulate 
while retrospectively quantifying crucial factors in the training process of successful 
athletes.

Over the last decades, there has been a clear trend for elite sports to work closer with 
academia to develop more evidence-based knowledge. Quantitative methods are used 
to enhance performance through optimization of equipment, training, and recovery, 
as well as nutritional factors. However, research in elite sports does not necessarily 
come without limitations. For the field of practice, such limitations may be the ability 
to read and understand scientific results. Therefore, "translation" of research findings 
to practice plays a crucial role while conducting applied research aiming to improve 
(elite) sports performance. Consequently, researchers should be good at “translating” 
and/or developing systems that “translates” research into relevant and applied 
knowledge for the practitioners. For example, in Norway, there are traditions for 
“translating” research findings to athletes and coaches through the sport government

“translating” research findings to athletes and coaches through the sport government 
body, Olympiatoppen. Over the last four decades, Olympiatoppen has worked closely 
with different research institutions in Norway and played an important role in the 
process of translating research-based knowledge to elite sports. Another limitation of 
23 
research in sports might be generalization of the research findings and bias that to 
different extent influence the results. Most research in sport science only include data 
on sub-elite athletes (i.e. more room for adaptations) and often exclusively on male 
participants, and it is therefore questionable to what extent much of the available 
literature can be generalized to more elite populations and/or female participants.

Moreover, research findings are often presented at a group level and the statistical 
results (e.g. effects of an training intervention) does not necessarily apply to each 
individual athlete although they provide important pieces to the knowledge puzzle. In 
(elite) sports, there are often large individual responses to training and other 
interventions (e.g. recovery and nutritional strategies), and each individual athlete 
represents a unique case (n=1) and should be treated thereafter. In other words, study 
samples in sport science research often constitute of multiple case studies. Therefore, 
research designs in elite sports including case studies and qualitative assessments may 
work as complementary to quantitative analyses of larger study samples to better 
understand performance development at the individual level. Taken these limitations 
into account, applied research on relevant aspects of elite sports can therefore not

into account, applied research on relevant aspects of elite sports can therefore not 
directly guarantee that performances will improve. Performance development in elite 
sports is a complex phenomenon and there is much we do not understand today about 
the mechanisms behind top sports performances. This is probably also the reason why 
intuition, experience, and tradition form the basis for training practice to a greater 
extent than the available scientific literature [116]. The results of scientific studies have 
probably not affected practice in sports to the extent that we as researchers often 
believe [117]. However, on the other hand, evidence-based knowledge through high-
quality research is of uttermost importance in several aspects of (elite) sports. Optimal 
interaction between research and practice has clear positive effects, and possibly even 
beyond what research or practice can achieve alone. The process of conducting

beyond what research or practice can achieve alone. The process of conducting 
research often provide positive synergies and contributes to good and fruitful 
discussions between researchers and practitioners. This is done by challenging each 
other with mutual respect and over time creating a larger performance development 
24 
than what would have been possible without this interaction. However, the interaction 
between research and practice will of course depend somewhat on the research 
carried out (e.g. basic vs. more applied research). A successful interaction between 
research and practice can be exemplified through the work that has developed the 
present theoretical framework of training in XC skiing, and the work constituting this 
dissertation, conducting applied research on its own professional practice at a sport 
high school. This work has initiated fruitful discussions between researchers and

high school. This work has initiated fruitful discussions between researchers and 
practitioners, as well as valuable experience and knowledge for the athletes involved 
in the different projects. Here, it has been experienced that to optimize the interaction 
between research and practice, researchers must perform applied work that has clear 
relevance and contributes to increased knowledge for athletes and coaches. However, 
there should also be room for more basic studies on aspects relevant for sports, as such 
questions are important parts of the knowledge puzzle. Moreover, practitioners must 
clarify what questions and knowledge gaps they are facing in their daily work as 
athletes and coaches. Here, it is important that researchers recognize and 
acknowledge aspects of professional practice such as tacit knowledge, as well as the 
multi-dimensional parts of the athletes training and development process. This

multi-dimensional parts of the athletes training and development process. This 
exemplifies the complexity of the training and recovery process, where often only one 
factor is isolated and investigated in research studies. In the next step, coaches and 
athletes need to adopt this factor into a complex and multifactorial process.

Furthermore, researchers must conduct work relevant for practice and develop good 
systems for knowledge-translation. The field of practice must challenge research and 
develop relevant questions where new knowledge over time contributes to improved 
practice. Researchers must further use high-quality methods to answer these research 
questions. Here, the combination of quantitative and qualitative designs might provide 
complementary understanding of the complexity of training and performance 
development. At the same time, researcher should not be afraid to challenge practice 
with questions and/or results, even though it may be in contrast with the athletes and 
coaches’ current practice. In addition to the actual research results published, the 
25 
process of performing research can contribute to positive discussions between 
researchers and practitioners, and thus per se have positive implications for improving

researchers and practitioners, and thus per se have positive implications for improving 
practice. All these perspectives have been highly relevant, while conducting the work 
constituting this dissertation and are therefore included in this chapter on scientific 
theory.

4. Methods 
This dissertation presents data from four published studies constituting two research 
projects conducted between 2019 and 2021. Studies I-II are based on a training 
intervention performed among Norwegian junior XC skiers, whereas studies III-IV are 
based on a sport collaboration between Norway and China, in which Chinese 
endurance athletes were transferred to XC skiing by employing Norwegian coaching 
and training methods. Both research projects were carried out at Meråker High School 
in Mid-Norway.

4.1 Participants 
In total, seventy-five (51 men and 24 women) endurance athletes participated in the 
two research projects (see Table 1 for detailed participant description). All the 
participants were classified as highly trained/national level athletes (Tier 3) according 
to the classification framework developed by McKay et al. [118]. The participants in 
studies I-II consisted of fifty-one (36 men and 15 women) junior XC skiers from Norway.

All athletes were students at a sport High School with a specialized study program for 
XC skiing. The participants in studies III-IV consisted of twenty-four Chinese endurance 
athletes (15 men and 9 women) with background in different Olympic summer sports 
(15 runners [middle- and long-distance] and 9 kayakers/rowers). For all analyses, the 
kayakers (n=7) and rowers (n=2) were pooled. These athletes were selected from the 
group of the second-best athletes in their respective sports in China and had trained 
professionally for this sport for several years. Therefore, they were given the 
opportunity to transfer to XC skiing while aiming for participation in the Beijing 2022 
winter Olympics.

28 
 
 
4.2 Ethical approvals 
The Regional Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics in Mid-Norway 
waived the requirement for ethical approval of these research projects (see appendix).

Therefore, the ethics of all studies is conducted according to the Declaration of Helsinki 
and the institutional requirements and approval for data security and handling 
obtained by the Norwegian Centre for Research Data (supplementary). Prior to the 
data collections, all athletes provided written informed consent to voluntarily take part 
in the studies. The athletes were informed that they could withdraw from the studies 
at any point in time without providing a reason for doing so. In study I-II, parental 
consent was additionally provided for athletes <18 years (n=21).

4.3 Study designs 
In studies I-II, a randomized, experimental design (randomized trial) was employed to 
investigate both the short-term and more subsequent effects of increased LIT vs. HIT 
during an 8-week intervention among junior XC skiers. In studies III-IV, a prospective, 
observational design was employed to examine the development of performance,

4.3.1 Study I-II 
Following an 8-week pre-intervention (baseline) period, the athletes were randomly 
allocated into either a group with increased load of LIT (LITG, n=26) or a group with 
increased load of HIT (HITG, n=25) for an 8-week intervention (simulating a general 
preparation period). The overall training load was balanced between groups using the 
training impulse method (TRIMP), and the groups were matched for age, sex, 
physiological indices, and pre-intervention training data. After the 8-week 
intervention, both groups performed a 5-week standardized training period following 
similar training regimes (simulating a specific preparation period). The goal of this 
period was to achieve similar training intensity distribution across groups. Accordingly, 
the 5-week period led to intensification both in the amount of HIT sessions and by 
increasing the intensity of HIT sessions for LITG, whereas HITG reduced the volume of

increasing the intensity of HIT sessions for LITG, whereas HITG reduced the volume of 
HIT but slightly intensified the stimulus. Subsequently, a 14-week follow-up period 
consisting of self-chosen training and competitions was included (competition period).

The complete study protocol is displayed in Figure 4. Performance and physiological 
profiling in both treadmill running and roller-ski skating (G3 sub-technique) were 
determined before (PRE), after the 8-week intervention (POST-1), and after the 5-week 
standardized training period (POST-2). In addition, an uphill running time-trial in the 
field at PRE and POST-1 was included in study I. Lastly, a treadmill roller-ski skating test 
(POST-3) was performed within the last week of the 14-week follow-up during the 
competition period in study II.

increased low- or high-intensity endurance training, and a subsequent 5-week standardized training 
period with similar intensity distribution.

4.3.2 Study III-IV 
After an initial 3-month introduction to roller-skiing in China, the athletes completed a 
6-month training period (talent transfer program) consisting of XC ski-specific training.

This was achieved by employing state-of-the-art training methods in XC skiing [2]. The 
athletes were assessed for performance, physiological, and technical indices in the 
laboratory during treadmill running and roller-ski skating (G3 sub-technique), double-
poling ergometry, as well as for upper-body, one-repetition maximum-strength (1RM) 
at baseline (PRE), after 3 (MID), and 6 months (POST) of training. Moreover, training 
data was recorded daily, and internal training load quantified using the session rating 
of perceived exertion (sRPE) method. In study IV, a performance index was developed 
to classify high- from low-responding athletes to the 6-month training period. Lastly, 
qualitative interviews of the athletes’ seven personal coaches were carried out directly 
after the 6-month period to provide a more holistic understanding of the training and 
recovery process (study IV).

31 
4.4 Test protocols  
Prior to all tests, the athletes’ training loads were standardized over the last two days 
to optimize performance levels and test-retest reliability. The athletes were instructed 
to avoid caffeine 24 hours and large meals 2-3 hours before reporting to the laboratory.
There was always a minimum of 24 hours of recovery between each laboratory visit.

All tests were performed in the same environmental conditions (18-22◦C and 30-40% 
relative humidity) and at the same time of the day (±2 hours) to avoid influence of 
circadian variations. Due to the substantial difference in sport-specific performance 
levels at baseline between the two study groups, different protocols were used to 
assess performance and physiological indices in roller-ski skating between study I-II and 
study III-IV.

4.4.1 Uphill running time-trial (study I) 
In study I, the athletes performed an uphill running time-trial in the field at PRE and 
POST-1. Prior to the time-trial, a ∼30-min self-selected warm-up was performed.

Performance times were recorded using two synchronized watches and the Race 
splitter timekeeping system (Makalu Logistics Inc, Fontana, USA). The time-trial was 
performed on asphalt with a total distance of 6.4 km (elevation: 270 m) and 4.5 km 
(elevation: 160 m) for men and women, respectively. The course and elevation profile 
are displayed in Figure 5.

Figure 5. Course and elevation profile of the 6.4 (men) and 4.5 km (women) uphill running time-trial 
used in study I.

32 
4.4.2 Treadmill running tests (study I-IV) 
Performance and physiological indices in running were determined using protocols 
developed by the Norwegian Top Sport Centre (Olympiatoppen) as previously 
described [37, 41]. Following a 10-min warm-up (60-72% HRmax), blood lactate profile 
testing was performed at a constant incline (10.5%) and individual adjusted starting 
speeds (~6 km·h-1 and ~7 km·h-1 for women and men, respectively), including 4-6 
periods of 5-min stages with a stepwise increase in workload (1 km·h-1) and 30-sec 
recovery between each stage (Figure 6). The blood lactate profile was considered 
complete when the athletes reached [La−] corresponding to ≥4 mmol·L-1. In study I-II, 
the athletes only performed one 5-min submaximal stage at the same absolute 
workload (8 km·h-1 for men and 7 km·h-1 for women) and therefore not a complete 
blood lactate profile. After a 5-min recovery period, the athletes performed an

blood lactate profile. After a 5-min recovery period, the athletes performed an 
incremental test to exhaustion to determine VO2max and performance indices (time to 
exhaustion [TTE] and peak speed [Vpeak]). The test was performed at 10.5% incline with 
a 1-km·h-1 increase in speed every minute until voluntary exhaustion (Figure 6).
Starting speed was set to 9 km·h-1 and 8 km·h-1 for men and women, respectively.
Figure 6. Protocol for the treadmill running and roller-ski skating tests used in study I-IV.

33 
4.4.3 Treadmill roller-ski skating tests (study I-II) 
Following a 10-min individual warm-up (60–72% of HRmax) in running, the athletes 
completed two 5-min submaximal stages at 5% incline while treadmill roller-ski skating.

The two stages were performed at the same absolute workload for men (12 and 14 
km·h-1) and women (10 and 12 km·h-1), with 1-min recovery in between. After a 5-min 
recovery period, VO2peak and performance measured as TTE and Vpeak were determined 
by an incremental test to exhaustion [56]. The test was performed at 5% incline with a 
starting speed of 14 and 12 km·h-1 for men and women, respectively. The incline was 
kept constant, while the speed was subsequently increased by 2 km·h-1 every minute 
up to 20 km·h-1 for men and 18 km·h-1 for women, and thereafter by 1 km·h-1 until 
voluntary exhaustion (Figure 6). The athletes were instructed to use the skating G3 
sub-technique during the entire protocol.

Figure 7. Example of an athlete during a treadmill roller-ski skating test used in study I-IV 
4.4.4 Treadmill roller-ski skating tests (study III-IV) 
Following a 10-min individual warm-up (60–72% of HRmax) in running, blood lactate 
profile testing was performed at a constant speed (9 km·h-1) and starting incline of 1.7% 
using a graded protocol, including 3-6 periods of 5-min stages with a stepwise increase 
34 
in workload (1.7%) and 1-min recovery between each stage (Figure 6). At the same 
absolute workload (5.2%), VO2 and video recordings were included to determine cycle 
characteristics, submaximal oxygen cost and gross efficiency. The athletes were 
instructed to use the skating G3 sub-technique during this stage, whereas they were 
instructed to freely choose sub-techniques for the rest of the test. The blood lactate 
profile was considered complete when the athlete reached [La−] of ≥4 mmol·L-1. After

profile was considered complete when the athlete reached [La−] of ≥4 mmol·L-1. After 
a 5-min recovery period, VO2peak and performance measured as TTE and Vpeak were 
determined [56]. The incremental test had a starting incline and speed of 7% and 9 
km·h-1, respectively. The incline was kept constant, while the speed was increased by 
1 km·h-1 every minute until exhaustion.

4.4.5 Double-poling ergometer tests (study III-IV) 
Initially, the athletes performed a warm-up consisting of 10-min running followed by 
3-min double-poling ergometry (60–72% of HRmax). Thereafter, the athletes conducted 
a modified 30-sec Wingate test and a 5-min self-paced double-poling performance test 
with a 5-min recovery period in between using protocols previously described [119, 
120]. The athletes were instructed to perform the 30-sec Wingate test as all-out, 
whereas instructions for an even, maximal pacing were given prior to the 5-min 
performance test to prevent “overpacing” during the initial part of the test.
Figure 8. Example of an athlete during a double-poling ergometer test used in study III-IV.

35 
4.4.6 Upper-body strength tests (study III-IV) 
The athletes were tested for 1RM upper-body strength on the same day as the 
treadmill running tests after a 20-min recovery period. 1RM was tested in the ski-
specific exercises, seated pull-down, and triceps press. For detailed description of the 
test protocols, the reader is referred to Losnegard, Mikkelsen, Ronnestad, Hallen, Rud 
and Raastad [107].  All 1RM tests were conducted using the same equipment with 
identical equipment positioning for each athlete, and all tests were supervised by the 
same test leader who gave verbal feedback to ensure proper technique. All athletes 
were familiar with the exercises before testing.

Figure 9. Illustration of upper-body 1RM testing using two ski-specific exercises seated pull-down 
(upper illustration) and triceps-press (lower illustration) used in study III-IV.

4.5 Measurements and calculations  
4.5.1 Physiological and performance measures (study I-IV) 
Running tests were performed on a 2.5 x 0.7-m motor-driven treadmill and roller-ski 
skating tests on a 3.5 x 2.5-m treadmill (RL 2500 and RL 3500E, Rodby, Vänge, Sweden).

36 
The treadmill belt consisted of non-slip rubber surface, allowing the athletes to use 
their own ski poles with special carbide tips during roller-skiing. All athletes used the 
same pair of skating roller-skis (IDT Sports, Lena, Norway) with standard category 2 
wheels. The roller-skis were pre-warmed through 10-min of roller-skiing before each 
test session and rolling friction force measured with a towing test as previously 
described by Sandbakk et al. [53]. The rolling friction coefficient (µ) was determined by 
dividing Ff by the normal force (Fµ = Ff /Fn) and included in the calculation of work rate.

For all submaximal tests, respiratory recordings were collected between the third and 
fourth minute of each 5-min stage and HR defined as the average over the last 30 sec 
of each stage. Respiratory variables were measured using open-circuit indirect 
calorimetry with mixing chamber and 30-sec averages of the respiratory variables 
collected (Oxycon Pro, Jaeger GmbH, Hoechberg, Germany). The instruments were 
calibrated against ambient air conditions and certified gases of known concentrations 
of O2 (15.0%) and CO2 (5.0%) before each test session. The flow transducer (Triple V, 
Erick Jaeger GmbH, Hoechberg, Germany) was calibrated using a 3-L high-precision 
calibration syringe (Calibration syringe D, SensorMedics, Yorba Linda, CA, USA). HR was 
continuously measured by a Garmin Forerunner 935 (Garmin Ltd., Olathe, KS, USA) and 
synchronized with the Oxycon Pro system. Rating of perceived exertion (RPE) using the

synchronized with the Oxycon Pro system. Rating of perceived exertion (RPE) using the 
6–20-point Borg scale [121] and [La−] in 20 µL of blood were taken from the fingertip 
directly after completing each submaximal stage. [La−] were measured using the 
stationary Biosen C-Line lactate analyzer (Biosen, EKF Industrial Electronics, 
Magdeburg, Germany). The device was calibrated every 60 min with a 12 mmol·L-1 
standard solution.

For the incremental tests to exhaustion, respiratory variables and HR were measured 
continuously, and VO2max/VO2peak defined as the two highest and consecutive 30-sec 
measurements. HRmax was defined as the highest 5-sec HR measurement, whereas RPE 
was determined directly after, and [La−] approximately 1-min after each test. Both TTE 
and Vpeak were used as performance indices in study I-IV. Vpeak was calculated as v = Vf 
37 
+ [(tT—1)Vd], where Vf is the speed of the last completed workload, t is the duration of 
the last workload, T is the standard duration of each workload, and Vd is the speed 
difference between the last two workloads [56].

4.5.2 Gross efficiency (Study I-IV) 
Gross efficiency was calculated as the ratio of work and metabolic rate according to 
Sandbakk et al [53]. Work rate was defined as the sum of power against gravity and 
friction:  
Pg+Pf = mgv (sin(α)+cos(α)µ) 
 
Pg = power against gravity; Pf = power against friction; m = body mass including all 
equipment; g = the gravitational constant; α = the treadmill incline; µ = frictional 
coefficient; v = treadmill speed. The aerobic metabolic rate was calculated as the 
product of VO2 and the oxygen energetic equivalent using the associated respiratory 
exchange ratio and standard conversion tables [122].

4.5.3 Cycle characteristics (Study III-IV) 
Cycle characteristics (i.e. cycle rate and cycle length) were determined by 2-D video 
recordings using an Apple iPad 4 (Apple Inc., California, USA) at 30 frames per second.

The video recordings were further analysed by the software Coaches Eye (TechSmith 
Corporation, Michigan, USA). The iPad was positioned on the left side of the treadmill, 
90° to the athletes’ skiing direction, providing a total view of the movement range of 
both skis and poles. Cycle time in the G3 sub-technique was taken as the time between 
two pole plants, and average cycle characteristics were determined by timing five 
cycles. Cycle length was then calculated by multiplying the speed of the treadmill by 
cycle time, whereas cycle rate was taken as the reciprocal of cycle time as described in 
previous studies [53].

38 
4.5.4 Training monitoring (study I-IV) 
In studies I-II, the athletes recorded their own training using an online training diary 
developed by the Norwegian Top Sport Centre (Olympiatoppen). In studies III-IV, day-
to-day training data were registered and systematized in detail for each athlete by 
Norwegian coaches and researchers contributing to the project. Days and/or sessions 
where the athletes were not able to follow prescribed training due to injury and/or 
illness were verified by a medical doctor and registered. The modified session-goal 
approach was applied [123] in all studies and the training systematized as training form 
(endurance, strength and speed), intensity (LIT, MIT and HIT) and mode (specific 
[roller-skiing/skiing] and non-specific [running and cycling]). For MIT and HIT sessions 
performed as intervals, time in the intensity zone of the session was registered from 
the beginning of the ﬁrst interval to the end of the last interval, including recovery

the beginning of the ﬁrst interval to the end of the last interval, including recovery 
periods. In addition, strength and speed training were registered from the start to the 
end of that separate part (e.g. strength, speed, plyometrics) during the session, 
including recovery periods. For detailed description of the training performed, the 
reader is referred to study I-IV.

4.5.5 Training load (study I-IV) 
In studies I-II, the TRIMP method was employed as the most valid method for the 
matching of endurance training intensity between the two intervention groups.

Accordingly, TRIMP was calculated by multiplying the duration in the three intensity 
zones with a weighting factor (i.e. LIT, MIT, and HIT are given a score of 1, 2, and 3, 
respectively). Total TRIMP was then obtained by adding the different intensity zone 
scores as previously described [77, 124]. In studies III-IV, training load was calculated 
using the sRPE load method [125]. After each training session, athletes reported their 
sRPE on a 1-10 scale to a researcher who was systematizing these data. Training load 
was then calculated by multiplying the athletes sRPE by the duration of the session in 
minutes [104]. Training load for all sessions was further summated to determine each 
athlete weekly training load for the entire 6-month training period.

39 
4.6 Qualitative assessments  
To gain a more comprehensive understanding of the multidisciplinary factors 
contributing to the individual training responses in study IV, semi-structured interviews 
with seven (one female) Norwegian coaches who worked as full-time coaches during 
the 6-month training period were performed. Their views on training load and quality, 
rate of injury and illness, physiological and technical development, as well as 
psychological and/or sociological differences between high- and low-responders were 
examined. All interviews were conducted face-to-face and tape-recorded in their 
entirety before being transcribed and analyzed. For these data, a content analysis was 
conducted independently by two researchers. All coaches volunteered for the study 
and signed an informed consent prior to their participation. For detailed descriptions 
of the methodology, the reader is referred to Sæther et al. [126].

4.7 Individual training responses  
In studies I-II, individual training responses were calculated using individual response 
magnitudes adopted from previous literature [98, 128]. These individual response 
magnitudes were summarized in three different categories: nonresponse defined as 
≤0% change, moderate response as 0% to 5% change, and large response as ≥5% 
change. Moreover, an adaptation index for each athlete was calculated as the mean of 
the percentage change in VO2max and Vpeak in running, as well as VO2peak and Vpeak in 
roller-ski skating from PRE- to POST [128].

In studies III-IV, a performance index was developed to classify high- and low-
responders to the 6-month training period. The performance index was based on PRE- 
to POST changes in Vpeak in running and roller-ski skating in addition to average power 
output in the 30-sec and 5-min performance tests double-poling ergometry. For 
detailed description of this calculation, the reader is referred to study IV. The relative 
(%) changes in these four performance indices were further summated by the following 
formula: 
40 
Performance index = %△Vpeak running (km·h-1) + %△Vpeak roller-ski skating (km·h-1) + 
%△Power output 5-min double-poling (w) + %△Power output 30-sec double-poling 
(w) 
4.8 Statistical analyses  
All data are reported as means ± standard deviations (SD). Assumption of normality 
was tested with a Shapiro–Wilk test in combination with visual inspection of 
histograms and qq-plots. To test for differences between groups, a univariate general

histograms and qq-plots. To test for differences between groups, a univariate general 
linear model (GLM) analyses of covariance (ANCOVA) was used, with the percentage 
change from PRE- to POST as the dependent variable, and baseline values as a covariate 
to adjust for possible between-group differences at baseline. Between-group 
differences in baseline and training characteristics were tested using an independent-
samples t-test in combination with Mann-Whitney U test. To test for significant PRE- 
to POST changes within groups, paired-samples t-test were applied and Wilcoxon 
signed rank test when data deviated from normally distribution. Effect sizes (ES) were 
calculated as Cohen’s d, and interpretations of the magnitude were as follows: 0-0.2 = 
trivial, 0.2-0.6 = small, 0.6-1.2 = moderate, 1.2-2.0 = large, and >2 = very large [127].

For all comparisons, statistical significance was set at an alpha level of p<0.05, and 
p=0.05–0.1 indicated trends. All data analyses were carried out using SPSS 27.0 (SPSS 
Inc, Chicago, IL, United States) and Excel 2016 (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, 
Washington, United States).

41 
5. Results
5.1 Study I-II 
5.1.1 Performance adaptations 
After the 8-week intervention, there were no differences between HITG and LITG in 
running time-trial performance changes (p=0.44, ES=0.06), although HITG improved by 
-2.3±3.2% (p=0.01), with no significant change in LITG (-1.5±2.9%, p=0.20, Table 2). In
the laboratory, changes in Vpeak during running did not differ between groups (p=0.30,
ES=0.10) but were improved in HITG (2.2±3.1%, p<0.01), with a corresponding non-
significant change in LITG (1.4±4.2%, p=0.18). Changes in Vpeak during roller-ski skating
did not differ between groups (p=0.20, ES=0.11) but were improved within both LITG
and HITG (1.5±2.4% and 2.5±3.4%, respectively, both p<0.01).

There was still no difference between LITG and HITG in Vpeak running changes (p=0.83, 
ES=0.08) after the subsequent 5-week period. However, a significant improvement was 
found in LITG (2.4±4.6%, p=0.04) and a corresponding trend towards improvement in 
HITG (1.8±3.9, P=0.09, Table 2). In roller-ski skating, no significant between-group 
difference in Vpeak was revealed (p=0.51, ES=0.20). However, within-group 
improvements were found in both LITG (3.3±3.3%, p<0.01) and HITG (2.6±3.1%, 
p<0.01). Lastly, no significant changes neither within nor between groups in Vpeak
during roller-ski skating were found 14 weeks later in the subsequent competition 
period.

5.1.2 Physiological adaptations 
The abovementioned performance adaptations were coincided by a between-group 
difference in VO2max running changes (p=0.04, ES=0.22) after the 8-week intervention.

VO2max in running tended to improve in HITG (3.0±6.4%, p=0.09), with a corresponding 
non-change in LITG (-0.7±4.6%, p=0.25). There were no between-group differences in 
any submaximal adaptations running at the same absolute workload. In roller-ski 
skating, there was a between-group differences in VO2peak changes after the 
42 
intervention (p=0.02, ES=0.18), with improvements in HITG (3.6±5.4%, p=0.01) and a 
corresponding non-change in LITG (-0.1±4.0%, p=0.62). Overall, positive submaximal 
adaptations in roller-ski skating at the same absolute workloads were found in HITG 
but not in LITG, although improvements in gross efficiency were similar between 
groups (Table 2).

5.1.3 Individual training responses 
Overall, large inter-individual variations in training responses were found in studies I-
II. The statistical findings from the 8-week intervention were further supported by the 
individual response magnitudes with 55% and 70% of the athletes in HITG 
44 
demonstrating moderate to large responses in Vpeak during running and Vpeak during 
roller-ski skating, respectively, with corresponding values of 41% and 64% for LITG. The 
individual response magnitudes for VO2max in running showed that 36% and 65% of the 
athletes in LITG and HITG, respectively, achieved moderate to large responses. Greater 
individual response magnitudes in HITG were also demonstrated for VO2peak in roller-
ski skating with 65% of the athletes demonstrating moderate to large response, with 
corresponding values of 45% in LITG. However, the better individual response 
magnitudes in HITG after the 8-week intervention were outbalanced after the 5-week

magnitudes in HITG after the 8-week intervention were outbalanced after the 5-week 
standardized training period, consistent with the abovementioned statistical findings 
(Figure 11). The individual response magnitudes for Vpeak in running showed that 42% 
and 45% of the athletes in LITG and HITG, respectively, achieved moderate to large 
responses. Similar patterns in individual response magnitudes were found for Vpeak in 
roller-ski skating with 65% of the athletes demonstrating moderate to large response 
in LITG, with corresponding values of 62% in HITG. For VO2max in running, 52% and 65% 
of the athletes in LITG and HITG, respectively, achieved moderate to large responses.

For VO2peak in roller-ski skating, 74% and 67% of the athletes in LITG and HITG, 
respectively, achieved moderate to large responses.
