5.2 Study III-IV 
5.2.1 Performance adaptations 
Vpeak in roller-ski skating improved significantly after the 6-month training period 
(13.1±8.3%, p<0.01, ES=1.56) for all athletes pooled, although there was no significant 
change in Vpeak during running (3.0±4.8%, p=0.12, ES=0.28, Table 3). Moreover, average 
power output in the 30-sec Wingate and 5-min performance tests double-poling 
ergometry improved significantly for all pooled (5.0±6.2%, p=0.04, ES=0.66 and 
7.8±9.3%, p<0.01, ES=0.34, respectively).

46 
5.2.2 Physiological adaptations 
There were no significant improvements in VO2max or any other physiological indices at 
submaximal workloads in running for all athletes pooled after the 6-month period. In 
roller-ski skating, no significant changes in VO2peak roller-ski skating were observed, 
although significantly lower physiological (e.g. VO2, HR, [La−], and RER) and perceptual 
cost, as well as improved power output at 4 mmol·L-1 were found at submaximal 
workloads. In addition, gross efficiency in roller-ski skating improved significantly for 
all pooled (0.6±0.6%-points, p=0.04, ES=0.59). No significant changes in VO2peak during 
the 5-min performance test double-poling ergometry were found. Lastly, 1RM upper-
body strength improved in the seated pull-down exercise (11.7±8.8%, p<0.01, ES=0.56) 
and the triceps-press exercise (10.7±8.7%, p<0.01, ES=0.53, Table 3).

47 
5.2.3 Sports background 
There was a larger improvement in Vpeak roller-ski skating among runners compared to 
kayakers/rowers (15.7±8.8% vs. 8.9±5.2%; p<0.01, ES=0.94), whereas the non-
significant changes in Vpeak in running did not differ between groups (2.6±5.2% vs.

4.1±7.0% in runners and kayakers/rowers, respectively; p=0.16, ES=0.24). Larger 
performance improvements among runners in roller-ski skating were coincided with a 
significant improvement in VO2peak, which differed from a corresponding non-change 
in kayakers/rowers (4.9±7.0%, p=0.04 vs. -0.9±5.1%, p<0.03, ES=0.75). These findings 
were further strengthened by better submaximal adaptations (i.e. power output at 4

5.2.4 High- and low-responders 
The individual response magnitude (performance index) among all athletes is displayed 
in Figure 13. Both VO2max in running and VO2peak in roller-ski skating improved among 
high-responders, in which differed from a small reduction among low-responders 
(5.0±6.8% vs. -1.3±4.4, p=0.04, ES=1.20 and 6.8±6.1% vs. -2.8±4.1%, p=0.02, ES=1.84, 
respectively). However, improvements in cycle length and gross efficiency while roller-
ski skating and VO2peak in double-poling ergometry did not differ between the two 
groups of responders after the 6-month training period.

The two groups did not differ in the number of rest days during the 6-month training 
period, but low-responders tended to have lower compliance to training, with on 
average 5 more days of injury and/or illness compared to high-responders (p=0.07, 
ES=0.74). Hence, high-responders performed 6% more total training (p=0.04, ES=1.23) 
and tended to complete more sessions than low-responders (p=0.08, ES=0.87). The 
larger total training time in high-responders consisted of 4% more endurance training 
distributed as 4%, 8% and 8% more LIT, MIT and HIT, respectively (all p<0.05, ES=0.90-
1.20), compared to low-responders. No differences in the amount of strength and 
speed training performed were found between groups. Weekly training load was 
significantly higher in high- compared to low-responders, and for most weeks the 
difference varied between ~8-25% (p<0.05. ES=0.60-1.30), with an average weekly 
training load for the 6-month period being 18% larger in high-responders (p=0.04,

training load for the 6-month period being 18% larger in high-responders (p=0.04, 
ES=1.20). For detailed description of the training characteristics between groups, the 
reader is referred to study IV.

6. Discussion 
The present dissertation investigated (1) both the short-term and more subsequent 
effects of increased low- vs. high-intensity endurance training on performance and

effects of increased low- vs. high-intensity endurance training on performance and 
physiological adaptations during the preparation period in junior XC skiers, and (2) the 
influence of adopting state-of-the-art training methods in XC skiing to athletes 
originating from other endurance sports in a talent transfer program. The main findings 
were as follows: 
Study I) Both increased load of LIT and HIT during the 8-week intervention period 
elicited significant performance adaptations such as improved uphill running time-trial 
performance and peak speed when incremental running and roller-ski skating to 
exhaustion in the laboratory during the preparation period of junior XC skiers.

However, there were no significant differences between groups in performance 
adaptations, although increased HIT elicited 3-4% greater improvements in VO2max 
running and VO2peak roller-ski skating compared to increased LIT.

Study II) The superior increase in VO2max running and VO2peak roller-ski skating in the 
group increasing HIT during the 8-week intervention period were outbalanced 
following a subsequent 5-week training period consisting of similar training regimes 
and intensity distributions. Moreover, no further changes in any performance or 
physiological indices in roller-ski skating neither within nor between the two 
intervention groups were found 14 weeks later in the competition period.

Study III) The 6-month talent transfer period elicited large improvements in 
performance indices during roller-ski skating and double-poling ergometry, whereas 
performance indices in running were unchanged. These changes were coincided with 
improved efficiency/work economy and longer cycle lengths during roller-ski skating, 
as well as improved 1RM upper-body strength. However, no changes in VO2max running 
and VO2peak roller-ski skating and double-poling ergometry were found at a group level.

Moreover, larger performance improvements in roller-ski skating and double-poling 
54 
ergometry were found in athletes originating from running compared to 
kayaking/rowing.

Study IV) High performance-responders to the 6-month training period demonstrated 
superior physiological adaptations both at submaximal and maximal workloads (i.e.
VO2max running and VO2peak roller-ski skating) than their low-responding counterparts.

These findings were coincided with higher training loads, greater perceived effort 
during sessions, and lower incidents of injury and illness in high- compared to low-
responders. Moreover, qualitative assessments of the athletes coaches highlighted 
that greater motivation and passion for XC skiing together with the ability to build a 
strong coach-athlete relationship separated high- from low-responders.

6.1 Study I-II 
Studies I-II investigated two different approaches to the theoretical framework of 
endurance training in XC skiing [2]. The 8-week intervention period (study I) per se was 
regarded as successful because most athletes improved their performance (~60% 
demonstrated moderate- to large performance responses). However, no significant 
differences in any performance adaptations were found between the intervention 
groups, although the distribution of individual response magnitudes indicated some 
more positive performance adaptations in the group increasing HIT. Therefore, the 
statistical findings in study 1 were somewhat in contrast to those previously reported 
by Stöggl and Sperlich [129] and Vesterinen et al. [130], who demonstrated superior 
performance adaptations of a more polarized intensity distribution with greater 
intensification (i.e. HIT stimulus) compared to high-volume LIT. Moreover, the findings

intensification (i.e. HIT stimulus) compared to high-volume LIT. Moreover, the findings 
were in contrast to the well-cited study by Helgerud et al. [88], demonstrating the 
superiority of HIT on indices of endurance performance using an iso-energetically 
matched method in a group of non-athletes. However, Ingham et al. [131] and Nuuttila 
et al. [132] found similar performance adaptations of both high-volume LIT and HIT 
regimes, which is consistent with the present findings and implies that similar 
performance progression can successfully be achieved both by increased load of LIT 
55 
and HIT during the preparation period in XC skiers. This is further supported by a recent 
case study on the most successful female XC skier of all time, employing two different 
intensity distributions and periodization models during her career (i.e. extensive HIT-
block periodization vs. more LIT focus and traditional periodization) [77], as well as

block periodization vs. more LIT focus and traditional periodization) [77], as well as 
more anecdotal evidence indicating individual variations in how XC skiers balance their 
training volume and intensity during the preparation period.

The tendencies for better performance adaptations in HITG during the intervention 
(distribution of individual response magnitudes) were outbalanced by within-group 
performance improvements in LITG during the subsequent 5-week training period 
(study II). Accordingly, intensification during this period had positive performance 
effects in LITG, although it remains unknown whether these improvements were 
caused by adopting more HIT per se or by the change from prioritizing high-volume LIT 
to more intensified training (i.e. traditional periodization model), which may elicit 
complementary adaptive responses [62, 64]. In comparison, performance indices did 
not change in HITG during the subsequent 5-week training period, which are likely 
explained by already maximized intensification-effects during the 8-week intervention.

These findings are consistent with a previous study by Sylta et al. [98] who found that 
most training adaptations elicited by intensification occurred already within the first 4 
weeks of a 12-week  intervention, investigating the effects of different HIT ordering 
and its adaptation time course in well-trained cyclists. However, it should be noted that 
the performance adaptations elicited during the 8-week intervention in HITG were 
maintained despite reduced volume of HIT in the subsequent training period.

During the 14-weeks of self-chosen training in the competition period (study II), no 
further changes in performance indices neither within- nor between the intervention 
groups were found. These findings agree with a previous study in elite male XC skiers 
[133], where most improvements in performance and physiological indices occurred 
during the preparation period, with only minor changes in the competition period.

These findings were, however, in contrast to a study with comparable design 
56 
conducted among well-trained cyclists, demonstrating positive effects of 
implementing HIT during an 8-week intervention in the transition period on 
performance indices 16 weeks into the subsequent preparation period [134]. Yet, 
these conflicting findings are likely explained by differences between implementing 
more HIT in the transition period where the overall training load is reduced vs. in the 
preparation period with higher training loads. Altogether, these findings indicate that 
differences in performance adaptations elicited by a typical short-term training 
intervention (8 weeks) had little or no effects on the development of performance 
indices in subsequent training periods.

Coincided with the abovementioned performance adaptations, increased load of HIT 
elicited superior physiological adaptations (3–4% increases in VO2max running and 
roller-ski skating) compared to increased load of LIT during the intervention period 
(study I). These findings were further strengthened by better distribution of individual 
response magnitudes in VO2max/VO2peak, as well as better physiological adaptations at 
submaximal workloads in HITG. Therefore, it seems obvious that the superior 
physiological adaptations in HITG had a positive effect on performance adaptations in 
study I. However, the reasons for improved performance in LITG without improving 
VO2max could be explained by increased fractional utilization. The superior VO2max 
adaptations in HITG are likely explained by increased O2 delivery capacity [86, 87, 93], 
which are supported by other short-term training intensification studies [88, 90, 91].

These findings implies that even when matching training intensities with a more 
ecologically valid method as employed in study I, a sufficient HIT stimulus seems 
needed to overload the cardiovascular system sufficiently and thereby increase VO2max 
more than when compensating with increased load of LIT [86, 93]. Altogether, 
progressing the overall training stimulus by intensification seems favorable if the goal 
is to elicit VO2max adaptations over a relatively short training period in XC skiers. These 
findings agree with retrospective analyses of XC skiers training emphasizing HIT in their 
preparation period with the goal of maximizing aerobic energy turnover capacities [76, 
77, 105]. However, no statistical differences in any physiological adaptations neither at 
57 
submaximal nor maximal workloads (TTE tests) were found between LITG and HITG 
after the subsequent 5 weeks with similar training regimes and after 14 weeks of self-

after the subsequent 5 weeks with similar training regimes and after 14 weeks of self-
chosen training in the competition period (study II). Accordingly, the subsequent 5-
week period with similar intensity distribution across groups, and thereby 
intensification for LITG, outbalanced the superior VO2max adaptations obtained by HITG 
during the preceding 8-week intervention period.

Interestingly, a considerably lower HIT stimulus during the 5-week training period 
elicited somewhat similar VO2peak adaptations when roller-ski skating in LITG compared 
to the effects achieved by HITG during the more intensive 8-week intervention. These 
findings may suggest a “ceiling-effect”, with an upper limit for how much HIT that is 
needed to maximize VO2max adaptations in already well-trained endurance athletes.

This hypothesis is partly supported by Billat et al. [135] who found that intensification 
beyond 1 HIT and 1 MIT session per week elicited no further adaptations but instead 
increased markers of maladaptation. Therefore, the present data suggests that 
although ~1 HIT and ~1 MIT session per week might be sufficient to maintain VO2max 
values, ~2-3 weekly HIT sessions are likely needed to maximize VO2max and other 
physiological adaptations over short time periods in endurance athletes. However, the 
volume and intensity within these intensity domains can vary extensively between 
sessions and adaptive responses from HIT and/or MIT are also dependent on optimal 
interaction between intensity and total work duration per session [136, 137]. In 
addition, the intensification-effects on VO2max in studies I-II occurred within a relatively 
short time frame which agrees with the findings by Sylta et al. [98]. Lastly, it should be

short time frame which agrees with the findings by Sylta et al. [98]. Lastly, it should be 
noted that the VO2max adaptations were only trivial to small within both groups (ES, 
0.1-0.3), which are somewhat lower than those found in comparable training 
intervention studies [98, 138]. The reason for this is not known but are most likely 
related to differences in athletes training status, duration of the intervention, and the 
training prescribed.

58 
It should also be emphasized that large inter-individual differences in training 
adaptations were found in studies I-II despite using a more ecologically valid approach 
with individual adjustments of load, which differed from most previous training 
interventions using similar load prescriptions. Overall, these findings provide 
complementary insights to retrospective training analyses of successful XC skiers, by 
demonstrating large individual responses to the theoretical framework of endurance 
training in XC skiing. In study I, the individual response magnitudes revealed that some 
athletes in LITG also increased VO2max to the same extent as HITG, indicating individual 
variations in how athletes respond to different endurance training intensities in 
eliciting physiological adaptations [100, 130]. This may in part be explained by 
between-athlete variations in adaptive signaling and stress tolerance to LIT and HIT

between-athlete variations in adaptive signaling and stress tolerance to LIT and HIT 
training. In addition, the present sample of athletes, including both sexes and different 
initial levels, could in part have contributed to the subsequent variations in training 
responses. However, the groups were matched for sex, physiological indices, and 
training characteristics pre-intervention, and baseline values were adjusted for as a 
covariate in the statistical analysis. Although the individual training responses were 
more equally distributed in study II, large individual responses were still evident, 
indicating that XC skiers respond different to different training intensities and 
periodization models. Accordingly, individualized training intensity distributions and 
periodization models (i.e. choosing the right method to the right athlete at the right 
time) are likely important to optimize long-term performance development in XC 
skiing.

In studies I-II, a more ecologically valid method than most previous training 
intervention studies was employed. In these studies, endurance training intensities 
(loads) have been matched for total work or oxygen consumption (i.e. iso-energetic 
method) [88, 90, 91]. The methodological approach in study I was based on the TRIMP 
method for matching of training intensity and induced a similar increase in overall 
TRIMP load in both intervention groups during the 8-week intervention [139, 140].

Accordingly, a significant between-group difference in LIT and HIT load was achieved 
59 
while obtaining similar overall training loads. Moreover, study II investigated the 
subsequent effects of the 8-week intervention on performance and physiological 
indices following a 5-week standardized training period with similar training intensity 
distribution across groups, and thereafter 14 weeks of self-chosen training and 
competitions. This approach differs from most previous training intervention studies 
where data on the interventions influence on the subsequent training periods or 
effectiveness of the interventions over longer time spans are lacking. Accordingly, the 
methodological approach in studies I-II provides novel data on both the short-term and 
more subsequent effects of load progression using different training intensity 
distributions during the preparation period in XC skiing.

6.2 Studies III-IV 
Studies III-IV provide unique data on a talent transfer process where athletes 
originating from different endurance sports (running and kayaking/rowing) were 
transferred to XC skiing by using the theoretical framework of endurance training in XC 
skiing (i.e. state-of-the-art training methods [2]) while aiming for participation in the 
Beijing 2022 Olympics. In fact, this was achieved by two of the athletes in the program, 
participating in several of the XC skiing events during the Beijing Olympics. Although 
some literature on individuals [112] and groups [113, 114] transferring from one sport 
to another exist, study III was the first study to investigate the development of 
performance, physiological, and technical indices among athletes transferring between 
endurance sports. Here, large performance improvements in sport-specific modes 
such as roller-ski skating and double-poling ergometry were found, whereas no

such as roller-ski skating and double-poling ergometry were found, whereas no 
performance changes were found in a general mode as running. The magnitude of 
performance improvement found between modes was clearly related to their technical 
complexity, where roller-ski skating demonstrated largest performance improvement 
due to more sport-specific and complex technical requirements compared to double-
poling ergometry and running (i.e. higher initial level and less room for adaptations).

These findings indicate that understanding differences between the performance and 
60 
physiological adaptations in general vs. sport-specific modes might be of particular 
importance in the process of transferring athletes between sports that requires new 
and complex technical demands.

Coincided with the abovementioned performance changes, maximal aerobic turnover 
rates (i.e. VO2max/VO2peak) did not change significantly in either of the exercise modes 
examined after the 6-month training period (study III). This was not unexpected in 
running among these already endurance-trained athletes with the majority of athletes 
originating from running but were more unexpected in roller-ski skating and double-
poling ergometry. This was particularly surprising considering the high VO2max/VO2peak  
values commonly reported among elite- to world-class XC skiers [36-41] performing 
whole-body work employing different exercise modes and the theoretical framework 
of endurance training in XC skiing [2]. However, surprisingly high VO2peak/VO2max ratios 
already before the 6-month training period (baseline) were found in roller-ski skating 
and double-poling ergometry in these unexperienced XC skiers, with ratios close to

and double-poling ergometry in these unexperienced XC skiers, with ratios close to 
those reported among elite XC skiers [2, 10]. This may indicate a limited potential for 
further improving VO2peak/VO2max ratios, combined with test protocols allowing the 
athletes to reach relatively high maximal aerobic turnover rates without being too 
much limited by their sport-specific inexperience (e.g. strength/power and technique).

Taken together, these findings implies that the observed sport-specific performance 
improvements in study III must be explained by the development of other 
performance-determining factors in XC skiing than improved maximal aerobic energy 
turnover.

The athletes demonstrated improved technique-specific upper-body strength in 
seated pull-down and triceps-press in study III (~10-12% improvements in 1RM). These 
strength adaptations corresponded with improvements in cycle length and gross 
efficiency during submaximal roller-ski skating which probably enhanced the athlete’s 
ability to improve sport-specific performance independent of changes in maximal 
aerobic energy turnover rates. Such improvements in technique-specific strength and 
61 
propulsion have previously been associated with longer cycle lengths and better work 
economy/efficiency in XC skiers [2, 53]. Accordingly, the findings from study III suggests 
that the development of performance indices during both roller-ski skating and double-
poling were most likely explained by improved sport-specific strength and power, 
leading to better technique-specific propulsion. Coincided with the observed

leading to better technique-specific propulsion. Coincided with the observed 
improvements in gross efficiency, lower physiological and perceptual costs were found 
when the athletes were compared at the same absolute submaximal workloads 
(speeds). This indicates that the submaximal workloads were less demanding and that 
sport-specific indices of anerobic threshold (e.g. power output at 4 mmol·L-1) while 
treadmill roller-ski skating were improved following the 6-month training period.

Finally, the athletes showed significantly higher RPE, HR, and [La−] values during the 
sport-specific incremental tests at POST, most likely explained by improved ability to 
push themselves and increase effort in a new mode.

In study III, the athletes with a background from running improved performance indices 
and power output at 4 mmol·L-1 in roller-ski skating more than the athletes with a 
background from kayaking/rowing. These findings were coincided with a 5% increase 
in VO2peak, that were significantly different from the unchanged VO2peak values roller-
ski skating among those athletes with a background from kayaking and rowing.

Runners also demonstrated a tendency towards improved VO2max in running (moderate 
ES). However, no between-group differences in the development of cycle length, skiing 
efficiency, or 1RM upper-body strength were revealed. This could possibly imply that 
despite having similar potential for developing technical and strength/power abilities 
in both groups, the runners were more likely to respond physiologically positive to XC 
ski-specific training by eliciting adaptations that improves maximal aerobic energy 
turnover. These findings were further supported by the findings in study IV, where 
most of the high responders had a sport background from middle- and long-distance 
running. The underlying mechanisms for the observed differences between runners 
and kayakers/rowers in sport-specific performance improvement are not known but 
imply overall lower adaptive responses among kayakers/rowers. This might be 
62

imply overall lower adaptive responses among kayakers/rowers. This might be 
62 
explained by a lower tolerance for high loads of endurance training in a new mode, 
possibly leading to maladaptation and negative training outcomes. Moreover, the 
runners might have been more familiar with the main exercise modes being utilized 
since a large amount of running was performed (30% of all endurance training), and 
classical skiing involves movements more closely related to the movement patterns of 
their sports background.

In study IV, the athletes classified as high-performance responders (i.e. overall largest 
performance development the modes investigated) improved their VO2max running and 
VO2peak roller-ski skating, whereas the low-performance responders displayed small 
reductions of these physiological indices over the 6-month training period. Better 
physiological adaptations among high-responders were additionally coincided with 
larger improvements in power output at 4 mmol·L-1 and more reduced physiological 
cost at the same submaximal workload roller-ski skating. However, the development 
of efficiency and cycle length did not differ between groups and were largely improved 
in both high- and low-responders. This is most likely explained by the low initial levels 
of both skiing efficiency and cycle length among these highly unexperienced skiers.

Accordingly, there was a large potential for improving efficiency and cycle length 
among all athletes. Overall, these findings demonstrate that the high responders were 
able to concurrently develop their maximal/peak aerobic turnover rates together with 
gross efficiency and cycle length. This ability is highly important as both skiing efficiency 
and VO2max/VO2peak are crucial performance determinants in XC skiing [2]. The largest 
difference in performance and physiological adaptations between the two groups of 
responders were found in roller-ski skating, indicating that differences in technical 
development could have influenced the greater performance development in high-
responders. Although the development of cycle length during treadmill roller-ski 
skating did not differ between groups, the coaches perceived that the high-responders 
clearly developed their on-snow technical skills to a larger extent than low-responders

clearly developed their on-snow technical skills to a larger extent than low-responders 
(study IV). Thus, more sophisticated measures (e.g. sub-technique selection and 
63 
kinematical patterns) than those included in our approach may have better detected 
these differences in technical development.

The difference in training volume between high- and low-responders during the 6-
month period was only 6%, but the largest relative difference was found in the 
amounts of MIT and HIT performed (~8% difference). Since this training is suggested 
to provide effective stimuli for the development of VO2max (as supported by the findings 
in study I), it may have contributed to the larger developments of maximal aerobic 
energy turnover rates among high-responders [141, 142]. In addition, the greater 
perceived effort during sessions found in high-responders could imply a higher 
motivation to maintain training effort during sessions and/or better ability to push 
themselves. This higher training tolerance might have elicited a greater overload 
stimulus and subsequently elicited better physiological adaptations through a larger 
external load (e.g. average speed or distance) during sessions in high-responders. The

external load (e.g. average speed or distance) during sessions in high-responders. The 
lack of physiological adaptations in low-responders are most likely caused by a lower 
training tolerance, possibly leading to maladaptation and states of non-functional 
overreaching in some of the athletes. This is further supported by the qualitative 
assessments of the athlete’s coaches, who reported that low-responders had less 
continuity in their training and more days of injury/illness. Furthermore, the coaches 
found it particularly challenging to find the optimal training load among low-
responders who also struggled to perceive and communicate the load-recovery 
balance to their coaches [143]. These findings highlight the importance of finding the 
optimal balance between load and recovery, while maintaining good health and 
avoiding injury and illness, to achieve long-term performance development in XC

avoiding injury and illness, to achieve long-term performance development in XC 
skiing. In addition, other factors than those measured in our design (e.g. nutrition, 
sleep quantity and quality, and genetic influence) could have contributed to explain 
parts of the observed variance in training responses between the two groups of 
responders in study IV [100].

64 
The athlete’s personal coaches reported motivation, passion, and a strong coach-
athlete relationship to be the most important factors associated with a high-training 
response during the 6-month period in study IV. While these factors might have an 
independent influence on athlete development, their impact might also be 
interrelated. A strong coach-athlete relationship between high-responders and their 
respective coaches may have played an important role in optimizing the individual 
training loads and thereby positively influenced the performance and physiological 
adaptations of these athletes. However, a strong coach-athlete relationship might also 
have positively influenced the athletes’ motivation and passion and vice-versa, and 
thereby reinforce the positive performance-development. For example, maintenance 
of motivation throughout the entire training period in high-responders might have

of motivation throughout the entire training period in high-responders might have 
contributed to their greater training effort and thus induced a larger overload stimulus 
and physiological development. Furthermore, higher passion for the training process 
and general well-being among high-responders might have enhanced the tolerance for 
and recovery from high training loads. In contrast, a less strong coach-athlete 
relationship combined with reduced performance-development in low-responders 
might have induced an imbalance between overall stress and recovery. Overall, these 
findings emphasize key psychological and sociological factors that coaches should 
consider when optimizing training adaptations and performance development in 
endurance athletes. For more detailed information on the qualitative factors 
separating high- from low-responders in study IV, the reader is referred to Sæther et 
al. [126].

6.3 Methodological considerations 
Although a more ecologically valid method for matching of endurance training intensity 
(load) was employed in study I, there is no consensus in the scientific literature 
considering the most valid method or weighing factor for different training intensities 
using a TRIMP-based methodology [77, 124]. Moreover, this methodology does not 
consider variations in metabolic vs. neuromuscular load between different exercise 
65 
modes (e.g. running vs. XC skiing). In studies II, training data during the 14-week follow-
up period was missing. Within- and between-group differences in training might 
therefore have influenced the findings on subsequent effects of the intervention, 
which were also performed on a reduced sample of athletes. However, the same 
coaches programmed individual training plans and employed similar training methods 
during this period as in the intervention and standardized training period. A potential

during this period as in the intervention and standardized training period. A potential 
limitation of studies III-IV was the lack of detailed background information of the 
athletes and their training characteristics during the period prior to the 6-months of 
training. Another limitation of studies III-IV was the relatively large variation in the 
duration of introduction period to roller-skiing before the 6-month training period.

However, no differences in the duration of the introduction period between runner 
and kayakers/rowers, as well high- and low-responders were found.

Moreover, studies I-IV only included laboratory performance indices and not real-
world performance outcomes that requires attention in future studies. However, all 
physiological and performance indices used in the present dissertation has shown to 
provide valid predictions of XC skiing performance (distance FIS points and simulated 
competition) in a heterogenous study sample [144]. Moreover, the present sample of 
athletes in studies I-IV included both sexes which might have influenced the observed 
training adaptations. However, no significant interactions of sexes were found in any 
performance or physiological adaptations and all group comparisons are therefore 
likely valid for both sexes. It may therefore be argued that this is more a strength than 
a limitation of the studies. However, adopting information on menstrual cycle phase 
and the use of hormonal contraceptives among female participants to the

and the use of hormonal contraceptives among female participants to the 
experimental design would have further strengthened the studies [145]. Lastly, 
classifying different responses to endurance training might be influenced by 
confounding factors such as technical measurement error and between-athlete 
variation (e.g. test-retest reliability) which should be considered in the interpretation 
of the results in studies I-II and study IV [146].

66 
6.4 Practical applications to cross-country skiing  
Studies I-II found that performance progression in XC skiing can successfully be 
achieved both by increased LIT and HIT in the preparation period, although a sufficient 
HIT stimulus seems beneficial for eliciting short-term physiological adaptations such as 
increased maximal aerobic turnover rates. However, training intensification during a 
typical short-term intervention has little or no effects on the subsequent performance 
and physiological development following a period of the same training regimes.

Therefore, based on the present findings, it could be argued that positive training 
effects found in previous and future short-term intervention studies should be 
interpreted with more caution until their effectiveness for more subsequent and/or 
long-term development has been shown. It may also be that positive training effects 
of different short-term interventions could in part be explained by changes in the 
training stimulus per se. Accordingly, there is a need for future training intervention 
studies in XC skiing investigating how manipulations of training intensity and volume 
are translated into performance and physiological benefits over longer time scales. This 
is important information for sport scientists and practitioners working with endurance 
athletes and would contribute to important understanding of endurance training 
optimization and performance development in XC skiing.

Studies III-IV provide unique insights into the application of the theoretical framework 
of endurance training in XC skiing (i.e. state-of-the-art training methods) to endurance 
athletes transferring to XC skiing in a talent transfer program. Here, the large 
improvements in sport-specific performance indices over a relatively short training 
period supports the application of such a program in XC skiing. However, careful 
consideration of the original sport and the characteristics of the potential transfer 
athletes, as well as a more long-term strategy than employed in the present studies 
are likely needed for success. Moreover, studies III-IV provide novel data on how 
athletes originating from other endurance sports progresses their maximal aerobic 
turnover rates, in addition to improving their technique, strength, and efficiency in 
67 
general vs. sport-specific modes, while transferring to XC skiing and applying state-of 
the-art XC skiing training.

68 
 
 
69 
7. Conclusions 
The present dissertation demonstrates that performance development can 
successfully be achieved both by increased load of low- and high-intensity endurance 
training during the preparation period in XC skiers, although increased high-intensity 
training may provide short-term benefits for maximal aerobic energy turnover.

However, the short-term effects of load progression by different endurance training 
intensities had little or no effects on the subsequent performance and physiological 
development following a period of similar training regimes.

Moreover, adopting the theoretical framework of endurance training in XC skiing on 
endurance athletes (i.e. runners, kayakers, and rowers) transferring to XC skiing elicits 
large sport-specific performance improvements while developments in maximal 
aerobic energy turnover were limited. Here, the athletes with largest development had 
a background from running and the ability to concurrently develop high aerobic energy 
turnover rates together with skiing efficiency, cycle length, and upper-body specific 
strength. However, a more long-term approach than employed in the present studies 
are clearly needed to reach a high international level in XC skiing following talent 
transfer initiatives.

Overall, the present dissertation provides novel understanding of both the short-term 
and subsequent effects of progressing endurance training volume and intensity in XC 
skiing, as well as the effects of applying state-of the-art XC skiing training to endurance 
athletes originating from other sports.

Effects of Increased Load of Low- Versus High-Intensity Endurance
Training on Performance and Physiological Adaptations
in Endurance Athletes
Rune K. Talsnes, Roland van den Tillaar, and Øyvind Sandbakk
Purpose: To compare the effects of increased load of low- versus high-intensity endurance training on performance and
physiological adaptations in well-trained endurance athletes. Methods: Following an 8-week preintervention period, 51 (36
men and 15 women) junior cross-country skiers and biathletes were randomly allocated into a low-intensity (LIG, n = 26) or
high-intensity training group (HIG, n = 25) for an 8-week intervention period, load balanced using the overall training impulse
score. Both groups performed an uphill running time trial and were assessed for laboratory performance and physiological
proﬁling in treadmill running and roller-ski skating preintervention and postintervention. Results: Preintervention to

proﬁling in treadmill running and roller-ski skating preintervention and postintervention. Results: Preintervention to
postintervention changes in running time trial did not differ between groups (P = .44), with signiﬁcant improvements in
HIG (−2.3% [3.2%], P = .01) but not in LIG (−1.5% [2.9%], P = .20). There were no differences between groups in peak speed
changes when incremental running and roller-ski skating to exhaustion (P = .30 and P = .20, respectively), with both modes
being signiﬁcantly improved in HIG (2.2% [3.1%] and 2.5% [3.4%], both P < .01) and in roller-ski skating for LIG (1.5%
[2.4%], P < .01). There was a between-group difference in running maximal oxygen uptake changes (P = .04), tending to
improve in HIG (3.0% [6.4%], P = .09) but not in LIG (−0.7% [4.6%], P = .25). Changes in roller-ski skating peak oxygen
uptake differed between groups (P = .02), with signiﬁcant improvements in HIG (3.6% [5.4%], P = .01) but not in LIG (−0.1%

uptake differed between groups (P = .02), with signiﬁcant improvements in HIG (3.6% [5.4%], P = .01) but not in LIG (−0.1%
[0.17%], P = .62). Conclusion: There was no signiﬁcant difference in performance adaptations between increased load of low-
versus high-intensity training in well-trained endurance athletes, although both methods improved performance. However,
increased load of high-intensity training elicited better maximal oxygen uptake adaptations compared to increased load of low-
intensity training.

Keywords: biathlon, endurance performance, maximal oxygen uptake, training intensity distribution, training volume, XC skiing
Endurance training involves the manipulation of training
intensity, duration, frequency, and mode, with the goal of maxi-
mizing physiological adaptations and performance.1,2 Accord-
ingly, the organization and optimization of endurance training,
and in particular training volume and intensity distribution, is
widely debated among both sports scientists and practitioners.1–3
Most elite endurance athletes adopt a training model consisting of
high volumes of low-intensity training (LIT) combined with low to
moderate amounts of moderate- (MIT) and high-intensity training
(HIT).1–3 However, the exact volume and training intensity distri-
bution depends on the demands of the given endurance sport,
individual requirements, as well as the phase of the annual training
cycle.1,3,4
Endurance athletes progress their overall training stimulus

individual requirements, as well as the phase of the annual training
cycle.1,3,4
Endurance athletes progress their overall training stimulus
throughout the annual cycle, which might be achieved through
increased load of LIT or by performing a larger load of MIT and/or
HIT.1 While LIT is seen as an important stimulus for inducing
peripheral adaptations such as increased mitochondrial biogenesis
and capillary density of the skeletal muscle,5,6 central adaptations
such as increased stroke volume of the heart, leading to improved
maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max), are regarded as more
responsive to HIT.5–7 However, LIT and HIT have many similari-
ties and both intensities seem to elicit complex and integrated
adaptations.1,5
To better understand how progression in endurance training
load by different intensity distributions inﬂuence performance and
physiological adaptations in endurance athletes, valid methods for
the matching of training load is required. The majority of previous

physiological adaptations in endurance athletes, valid methods for
the matching of training load is required. The majority of previous
intervention studies where training load has been matched for total
work or oxygen consumption (iso-energetic method) emphasizes
the superiority of HIT for maximizing physiological adaptations.7-9
However, such studies are not realistic from the perspective of how
endurance athletes train and perceive stress,3 since endurance
athletes can perform far more work, both energetically and in
terms of total work at a lower autonomic disturbance, with LIT
compared to HIT.10 Accordingly, progressing the overall training
stimulus with increased load of LIT may be advantageous for
optimizing adaptative responses at a tolerable level of stress,
although most experimental evidence suggests superior adapta-
tions while adopting a more polarized intensity distribution11 with
greater training intensiﬁcation.12

tions while adopting a more polarized intensity distribution11 with
greater training intensiﬁcation.12
Therefore, the present study compared the effects of increased
load of LIT versus HIT during an 8-week intervention period on
performance and physiological adaptations in well-trained endur-
ance athletes. This was done by matching the increase of LIT and
HIT for overall load by the training impulse method (TRIMP), in
which we hypothesized that more HIT would elicit superior
VO2max adaptations and thereby greater performance improve-
ments compared to more LIT over 8 weeks.

ORIGINAL INVESTIGATION
Methods
Participants
Fifty-one (36 men and 15 women; Table 1) national-level junior
cross-country skiers and biathletes volunteered to participate in the
study. All athletes were students at a Norwegian high school with a
specialized study program for cross-country skiing (n = 41) and
biathlon (n = 10). The Regional Committee for Medical and Health
Research Ethics waived the requirement for ethical approval for
this study. Therefore, the ethics of the study are in accordance with
the institutional requirements, and approval for data security and
handling obtained from the Norwegian Centre for Research Data.

All athletes were fully informed of the nature of the study and its
experimental risks before providing written consent. Several ath-
letes (n = 21) were <18 years, and therefore, the parents were asked
to provide parental consent. Some athletes dropped out of the study
(low-intensity training group [LIG] = 2; high-intensity training
group [HIG] = 5) due to sickness (n = 3), injury (n = 2), or other
reasons (n = 2). In addition, 2 athletes from LIG were excluded
from the ﬁnal analyses due to lack of 85% compliance with the
prescribed training.

Design
Following an 8-week preintervention period, the athletes were
randomly allocated into either a group with increased load of
LIT (LIG, n = 26) or a group with increased load of HIT (HIG,
n = 25) for an 8-week intervention during their late preparation
period (September–November). The training was balanced for
overall load using a TRIMP score, and groups were matched for
sport, age, sex, physiological indices, and preintervention training
characteristics. Both groups performed an uphill running time trial
(TT) in the ﬁeld and were assessed for laboratory performance and
physiological proﬁling in treadmill running and roller-ski skating
before (pre) and after (post) the intervention.

Prior to the intervention, all athletes
followed an 8-week baseline period consisting of the same training
guidelines. The athletes were instructed to focus on high-volume
LIT interspersed with, on average, 1 weekly MIT and 1 weekly HIT
session. In addition, 2 to 3 weekly strength or speed sessions were
integrated into LIT sessions or performed as a single session. Based
on this, individualized training programs were developed together
with the athlete’s personal coaches to ensure optimal adjustments
of load. The athletes were familiarized with the different test
protocols before performing all pretests during the last week of
the preintervention period.

Training plans during the 8-week interven-
tion period were based on a theoretical framework developed by the
researchers and adopted to each athlete in close collaboration with
coaches. The groups increased their overall training load in the
intervention period by adopting 2 different training regimes. LIG
continued with the same focus as during the preintervention period,
but with increased volume of LIT, whereas HIG changed toward
increased frequency and volume of HIT with reduced volume of
LIT. Weekly mesocycle load was designed with 3 different load
structures (high, moderate, and low) for both groups, where the
coaches, individually adjusted and optimized load for each athlete.

Based on previous research13,14 and pilot testing of selected
athletes, the use of the TRIMP method was incorporated as the
most valid method for the matching of training load between
groups. Accordingly, all within-group mesocycle loads were bal-
anced for overall load (TRIMP) between groups. TRIMP was
calculated by multiplying the duration in 3 intensity zones with
a weighting factor (ie, LIT, MIT, and HIT are given a score of 1, 2,
and 3, respectively). Total TRIMP was then obtained by adding the
different intensity zone scores. Distribution of MIT and HIT
sessions per week together with weekly mesocycle loads for
both groups are displayed in Figure 1. All athletes were instructed
to maintain the same diet, and training plans were designed to
maintain similar volume of strength and speed training during the
intervention period.

All athletes recorded their own training
using an online training diary developed by the Norwegian Top
Sport Centre (Olympiatoppen) by applying the modiﬁed session-
goal approach.15 Training intensity distribution was recorded
using a 5-zone intensity scale but reported using a 3-zone scale
(LIT, MIT, and HIT), which better corresponds with relevant
literature and underlying physiological mechanisms.16 For MIT
and HIT sessions performed as intervals, time in the intensity zone
of the session was registered from the beginning of the ﬁrst interval
to the end of the last interval, including recovery periods. More-
over, strength and speed training was registered from the start to the
ﬁnish of that separate part (eg, strength, speed, plyometrics) during

the session, including recovery periods. Training mode is reported
as speciﬁc (classical and skating roller-skiing) and nonspeciﬁc
(running and cycling) endurance training. In addition, intensity
control was achieved by regular use of heart rate (HR) monitoring
and [La−] measurements throughout the intervention period.

Test Protocols and Measurements
Training plans were designed to include standardized training load
in the last 2 days prior to the ﬁrst day of testing. The athletes were
instructed to follow self-selected preparation procedures and not to
consume any large meals or caffeinated beverages within the last
2 hours before the test. There were always >24 hours between all
tests for each athlete. The TT in combination with laboratory tests
were chosen to obtain a comprehensive understanding of perfor-
mance both in practical and laboratory conditions, as well as the
underlying physiological mechanisms.

Prior to the TT, athletes
performed a ∼30-minute LIT self-selected warm-up procedure.

Performance times were recorded using 2 synchronized watches
and the Racesplitter timekeeping system (Makalu Logistics Inc,
Fontana, CA). The TT was performed on asphalt with a total
distance of 6.4 km (elevation: 270 m) and 4.5 km (elevation:
160 m) for men and women, respectively. Weather conditions were
stable during each test day, being partly cloudy with low and stable
wind, but differed in ambient temperature and humidity between
pre and post (15°C vs 2°C and 70% vs 90%, respectively). Due to
different reasons, 6 athletes in LIG and 1 athlete in HIG were not
able to perform the TT at both pre and post. Hence, 35 athletes were
included in the ﬁnal TT analysis (LIG, 10 men and 5 women; HIG,
14 men and 5 women).

Following a
10-minute individual running warm-up (60%–72% of maximal HR
[HRmax]), all athletes performed one 5-minute submaximal stage
running at 10.5% incline and at the same absolute speed (8 km·h−1
for men and 7 km·h−1 for women). After a 2-minute recovery
period, the athletes performed an incremental test to exhaustion in
order to determine VO2max and performance measured as peak
treadmill speed ([Vpeak] calculated according to Sandbakk et al17).

The test was performed at 10.5% incline with a 1 km·h−1 increase in
speed every minute until voluntary exhaustion. Starting speed was
set to 9 km·h−1 and 8 km·h−1 for men and women, respectively.
Laboratory Treadmill Roller-Ski Skating Test (Test Day 3).

After
a 10-minute individual running warm-up (60%–72% of HRmax) as
on test day 2, the athletes completed two 5-minute submaximal
stages at 5% incline while treadmill roller-ski skating. The 2 stages
were performed at the same absolute speed for men (12 and
14 km·h−1) and women (10 and 12 km·h−1), with 1-minute recovery
in between. Following a 5-minute recovery period, peak oxygen
uptake (VO2peak) and performance measured as Vpeak were

(Ahead of Print)
determined.17 The test was performed at 5% incline with a starting
speed of 14 and 12 km·h−1 for men and women, respectively. The
incline was kept constant, while the speed was subsequently
increased by 2 km·h−1 every minute up to 20 km·h−1 for men
and 18 km·h−1 for women, and thereafter by 1 km·h−1 until
voluntary exhaustion. The athletes were instructed to use the
skating G3 subtechnique during the entire test.

Treadmill running was performed on a 2.5 × 0.7-m motor-
driven treadmill and treadmill roller-ski skating on a 3.5 × 2.5-m
treadmill (RL 2500 and RL 3500E; Rodby Innovation, Vänge,
Sweden). For all submaximal testing, respiratory recordings were
collected between the third and fourth minute of each 5-minute stage
and HR deﬁned as the average over the last 30 seconds. Respiratory
variables were measured using open-circuit indirect calorimetry
with mixing chamber (Oxycon Pro; Jaeger GmbH, Hoechberg,
Germany) and HR by a Garmin Forerunner 935 (Garmin Ltd,
Olathe, KS). Rating of perceived exertion (RPE) using the 6- to
20-point Borg scale and [La] from the ﬁngertip was taken directly
after completing each stage. [La−] was measured using the stationary
Biosen C-Line lactate analyser (Biosen; EKF Industrial Electronics,
Magdeburg, Germany). In addition, gross efﬁciency was measured
for the submaximal roller-ski stages and deﬁned as the ratio of work

Magdeburg, Germany). In addition, gross efﬁciency was measured
for the submaximal roller-ski stages and deﬁned as the ratio of work
and metabolic rate.18 For the incremental test to exhaustion, respi-
ratory variables and HR were measured continuously, and VO2max/
peak deﬁned as the highest 1-minute average. HRmax was deﬁned as
the highest 5-second HR measurement, whereas RPE was deter-
mined directly after, and [La−] approximately 1 minute after.

Statistical Analysis
All data are reported as mean (SD). Assumption of normality was
tested with a Shapiro–Wilk test in combination with visual inspec-
tion of histograms. Adopted from previous literature,19,20 individ-
ual
response
magnitudes were
summarized
in
3
different
categories: nonresponse deﬁned as <0% change, moderate
response as 0% to 5% change, and large response as >5% change.

An adaptation index for each athlete was also calculated as the
mean of the percentage change in treadmill running VO2max and
Vpeak, treadmill roller-ski skating VO2peak and Vpeak from pre to
post.20 To test for differences between groups, a univariate general
linear model analysis of covariance was used, with the percentage
change from pre to post as the dependent variable, and baseline
values as a covariate to adjust for possible between-group differ-
ences preintervention. Pre to post changes within groups were
assessed using a paired-samples t test. Between-group differences
in baseline and training characteristics were tested using an inde-
pendent samples t test. Effect size was calculated as Cohen d by
using the mean pre to post change between groups, divided by the
pooled pretest SD (interpreted as follows: 0.0–0.24 trivial, 0.25–
0.49 small, 0.5–1.0 moderate, and >1.0 large).21 For all compar-
isons, statistical signiﬁcance was set at an alpha level of P < .05,

0.49 small, 0.5–1.0 moderate, and >1.0 large).21 For all compar-
isons, statistical signiﬁcance was set at an alpha level of P < .05,
and P = .05 to .1 indicated trends. All data analyses were conducted
using SPSS (version 26.0; SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL).

Results
Training Characteristics
Comparisons of training characteristics between groups are shown
in Table 2. Weekly TRIMP during the preintervention and inter-
vention periods did not differ between groups (P = .60 and P = .93,
respectively), whereas the training intensity distribution shifted
from having a similar pattern across groups during the preinterven-
tion to clearly differing during the intervention. During the inter-
vention period, LIG performed 16% more endurance training hours
compared to HIG (P < .01), due to 25% more hours of LIT
(P < .01). HIG performed 118% more hours of HIT compared to
LIG (P < .01), whereas hours of MIT did not differ between groups
(P = .35). The volume of strength and speed training performed
during the intervention period did not differ between groups
(P = .67 and .23, respectively).

Baseline Characteristics and Body Mass
There were no differences between groups in age, anthropometrics,
or any performance or physiological indices before the interven-
tion. There were no between-group differences in body mass
changes (P = .12), although an increase was observed in HIG
(1.9% [2.2%], P < .01), but not in LIG (0.5% [2.1%], P = .19).

Performance Adaptations
There were no between-group differences in running TT perfor-
mance changes (P = .44), but HIG improved by −2.3% (3.2%)
(P = .01), with no change in LIG (−1.5% [2.9%], P = .20). The
individual response magnitudes for TT performance changes are
shown in Figure 2. The changes in treadmill running Vpeak did not
differ between groups (P = .30) but were improved in HIG (2.2%
[3.1%], P < .01), with a corresponding nonchange in LIG (1.4%
[4.2%], P = .18; Table 3). Treadmill roller-ski skating Vpeak
changes did not differ between groups (P = .20), but were improved
within both LIG and HIG (1.5% [2.4%] and 2.5% [3.4%], respec-
tively, both P < .01).

Physiological Adaptations
There was a between-group difference in treadmill running VO2-
max changes (P = .04; Table 3), tending to improve in HIG (3.0%
[6.4%], P = .09), with a corresponding nonchange in LIG (−0.7%
[4.6%], P = .25). There were no between-group differences in
submaximal adaptations running at absolute speeds, although
trivial to small effects of reduced respiratory exchange ratio,
HR, %HRmax, and RPE in HIG versus LIG were found (see Table 3
for all details).

The change in treadmill roller-ski skating VO2peak was
different between groups (P = .02), with improvements in HIG
(3.6% [5.4%], P = .01) and a corresponding nonchange in LIG
(−0.1% [4.0%], P = .62). Overall, positive submaximal adaptations
(ie, %VO2max, respiratory exchange ratio, %HRmax, and RPE) in
roller-ski skating at absolute speeds were found in HIG and not in
LIG, although gross efﬁciency was improved in both groups (see
Table 4 for all details). Individual response magnitudes for Vpeak
and VO2max/peak in treadmill running and roller-ski skating are
presented in Figure 3, while Figure 4 shows the adaptation index
for each athlete in LIG and HIG.

Discussion
The present study compared the effects of increased load of LIT
versus HIT on performance and physiological adaptations in well-
trained endurance athletes. The main ﬁndings were that perfor-
mance adaptations, including uphill running TT performance and
peak speed when incremental running and roller-ski skating to
exhaustion in the laboratory, did not differ signiﬁcantly between
4
Talsnes, van den Tillaar, and Sandbakk
(Ahead of Print)
the 2 groups progressing their training with different endurance
training intensities. However, while both groups improved their
performance, increased load of HIT elicited 3% to 4% greater
changes in running VO2max and roller-ski skating VO2peak
compared to increased load of LIT.

In contrast to most previous intervention studies where
endurance training load is matched for total work or oxygen
consumption,7–9 the present approach induced a similar increase
in TRIMP load when progressing the overall training stimulus
for both groups.22,23 Accordingly, a signiﬁcant between-group
difference in LIT and HIT load was achieved while obtaining
similar training loads. Although the intervention per se was
regarded as successful because most athletes improved their
performance, there are potential limitations with this approach
caused by, for example, between-athlete variations in adaptive
signaling and stress tolerance to LIT and HIT training. In
addition, this approach does not consider variations in metabolic
versus neuromuscular load between different training modes
(eg, running vs XC skiing). Although there was a change toward
more speciﬁc training in the intervention period compared to
baseline training, these changes were nonsigniﬁcant and similar

more speciﬁc training in the intervention period compared to
baseline training, these changes were nonsigniﬁcant and similar
between groups. Accordingly, the design could be regarded valid
for the purpose of the study.

With such matching of training load progression, the present
study found little or no effects on performance adaptations in
running or roller-ski skating when increasing the load of LIT
versus HIT in well-trained endurance athletes. Although the
individual response magnitudes indicated more positive perfor-
mance adaptations in HIG, the present statistical ﬁndings are in
contrast to those of Stöggl and Sperlich11 and Vesterinen et al,24

who demonstrated superior performance adaptations of a more
polarized intensity distribution with greater HIT load compared to
high-volume LIT regimes. However, Ingham et al25 and Nuuttila
et al26 found similar performance adaptations of high-volume LIT
and HIT regimes, which is in line with the present ﬁndings and
implies that similar performance progression can be achieved both
by increased load of LIT and HIT during the preparation period in
endurance athletes.

In accordance with the hypothesis, increased load of HIT led
to 3% to 4% better VO2max adaptations in running and roller-ski
skating compared to increased load of LIT. These ﬁndings were
strengthened by the greater individual response magnitudes and
adaptation index as well as better submaximal adaptations
(eg, reduced HR) at absolute speeds in HIG. Better VO2max
adaptations in HIG are likely explained by increased O2 delivery
capacity,5,6,12 supported by other short-term training intensiﬁca-
tion studies.7–9 This argues that even when matching training
load with a more ecologically valid method as employed here, a
high HIT stimulus seems needed to stress the cardiovascular
system sufﬁciently and will thereby increase VO2max more than
when compensating with increased load of LIT.5,12 Still, only
trivial to small effects in the differences in physiological adapta-
tions were found, which is likely explained by the relatively high

trivial to small effects in the differences in physiological adapta-
tions were found, which is likely explained by the relatively high
training status and the short intervention period.27–29 Altogether,
progressing the overall training stimulus by intensiﬁcation
seems favorable if the goal is to elicit VO2max adaptations
over a relatively short training period in well-trained endurance
athletes. To what extent these adaptations can be transferred also
to performance beneﬁts over a longer timescale requires further
examination.

The individual response magnitudes revealed that some ath-
letes in LIG also improved their VO2max to the same extent as
HIG, indicating individual variations in how athletes respond to
different endurance training in eliciting VO2max.24,30 The present
sample of athletes, including both sexes and different initial levels,
could, in part, have contributed to the subsequent variations

7
(Ahead of Print)
in training response. However, the groups were matched for sex
and physiological indices preintervention, and baseline values
were adjusted for as a covariate in the statistical analysis. In this
context, no signiﬁcant sex differences in any performance or
physiological adaptations were found. Accordingly, the present
group comparisons are likely valid, although future studies should
further investigate individual responses to changes in training
volume and intensity distribution, as well as overall load adjust-
ments in endurance athletes.

It seems obvious that improved VO2max had a positive effect
on performance adaptations in HIG. However, the reasons for
improved performance in LIG without improving VO2max could
be explained by increased fractional utilization of VO2max
(ie, anaerobic threshold). In this context, an interesting feature
is that the number of LIT sessions above 2.5 hours in LIG might
have provided a different stimulus for adaptive signaling than
shorter LIT sessions. Accordingly, the hypothesis was that LIT
and HIT induce complementary adaptations, which is partly
induced through different molecular pathways.1,5 However, this
remains speculative as muscle biopsies or other measures to
examine underlying mechanisms were not included in the present
design.

Practical Applications
The data presented in this study provide novel information with
relevance for optimizing the training volume and intensity distri-
bution in periods when the overall training stimulus is progressed
in endurance athletes. The present data indicate that performance
progression can be achieved both by increased load of LIT and
HIT, although a sufﬁcient HIT stimulus seems to be beneﬁcial for
eliciting maximal energy delivery capacities in 8 weeks. However,
the more long-term effects and the effect of different periodization
models of LIT and HIT focus prior to the competition period
require further attention in future studies.

Conclusions
The present study found no signiﬁcant difference in performance
adaptations in running or roller-ski skating during 8 weeks of
increased load of LIT versus HIT in well-trained endurance
athletes, although both methods improved performance. However,
increased load of HIT elicited better VO2max adaptations com-
pared to increased load of LIT.

How Do the Effects of an 8-Week Intervention Inﬂuence
Subsequent Performance Development in Cross-Country Skiers?

Rune K. Talsnes, Lars Jonatan Engdahl, and Øyvind Sandbakk
Purpose: To investigate how the effects of increased low- versus high-intensity endurance training in an 8-week intervention
inﬂuenced the subsequent development of performance and physiological indices in cross-country skiers. Methods: Forty-four
(32 men and 12 women) junior cross-country skiers were randomly assigned into a low-intensity training group (LITG, n = 20) or
high-intensity training group (HITG, n = 24) for an 8-week intervention followed by 5 weeks of standardized training with similar
intensity distribution, and thereafter 14 weeks of self-chosen training. Performance and physiological indices in running and in
roller-ski skating were determined preintervention, after the intervention, and after the standardized training period. Roller-ski
skating was also tested after the period of self-chosen training. Results: No between-groups changes from preintervention to after

skating was also tested after the period of self-chosen training. Results: No between-groups changes from preintervention to after
the standardized training period were found in peak speed when incremental running and roller-ski skating (P = .83 and .51),
although performance in both modes was improved in the LITG (2.4% [4.6%] and 3.3% [3.3%], P < .05) and in roller-ski skating
for HITG (2.6% [3.1%], P < .01). While improvements in maximal oxygen consumption running and peak oxygen uptake roller-
ski skating were greater in HITG than in LITG from preintervention to after the intervention, no between-groups differences were
found from preintervention to after the standardized training period (P = .50 and .46), although peak oxygen uptake in roller-ski
skating signiﬁcantly improved in HITG (5.7% [7.0%], P < .01). No changes either within or between groups were found after the

skating signiﬁcantly improved in HITG (5.7% [7.0%], P < .01). No changes either within or between groups were found after the
period of self-chosen training. Conclusions: Differences in adaptations elicited by a short-term intervention focusing on low-
versus high-intensity endurance training had little or no effect on the subsequent development of performance or physiological
indices following a period of standardized training in cross-country skiers.

Keywords: endurance training, training intensity, training volume, periodization, XC skiing
Manipulation of training intensity and volume is a key factor
for optimizing adaptive responses to endurance training.1–4 Retro-
spective analyses have demonstrated that successful elite endur-
ance athletes prioritize high volumes of low-intensity training
(LIT) combined with low to moderate amounts of moderate-
intensity training (MIT) and high-intensity training (HIT) in the
general preparation period. Thereafter, the speciﬁc and/or compe-
tition period is often characterized by reduced volume and more
intensiﬁed training.1–3
Performance improvements in the competition period follow-
ing intensiﬁcation is supported by several short-term experimental
studies showing superior training adaptations while adopting a
more polarized intensity distribution with augmented HIT stimu-
lus.5–7 Speciﬁcally, it has been argued that intensiﬁcation is needed

more polarized intensity distribution with augmented HIT stimu-
lus.5–7 Speciﬁcally, it has been argued that intensiﬁcation is needed
to further elicit physiological adaptations (eg, maximal oxygen
uptake [VO2max]) in already well trained to elite endurance
athletes.7–10 However, the majority of previous training studies
are limited by employing methods for matching of training load
that are not valid (ie, isoenergetic method) and/or by using short
intervention periods (4–12 wk). Consequently, we do not know
how the effect of short-term training interventions would inﬂuence
the subsequent training periods or if their effectiveness would be
maintained over longer time spans. In this context, intensiﬁed
training in the transition period of well-trained cyclists led to
more positive performance development in the subsequent training
period.11 However, the long-term effects of short-term training
interventions during the preparation period in endurance athletes is
currently unexplored.

In a recent study,12 progression of training load by increased HIT
during an 8-week intervention period elicited 3% to 4% greater
VO2max adaptations than progressing the load by increased volume
LIT, although the performance development did not statistically differ
between the groups of cross-country (XC) skiers. Both training
regimes were matched for overall load, and these ﬁndings indicate
an intensity-dependent diversity in the development of performance-
determining physiological factors. However, the extent to which these
differences in training adaptations inﬂuence the subsequent develop-
ment of performance and physiological indices is yet unknown.

Therefore, the main purpose of this follow-up study was to
investigate how the effects of increased LIT versus HIT in an
8-week intervention period inﬂuenced the subsequent development
of performance and physiological indices in well-trained XC
skiers. This was achieved by comparing the further development
in performance and physiological adaptations following 5 weeks of
standardized training with similar intensity distribution across
groups, and thereafter 14 weeks of self-chosen training.

Methods
This study expands upon the ﬁndings of a recent training interven-
tion conducted among well-trained junior XC skiers in their
preparation period.12 Following an 8-week preintervention period
(July–August), the athletes were randomly assigned into either a
group with increased load of LIT (LITG) or HIT (HITG) for an 8-
week intervention (September–October) simulating a general

Thereafter, the athletes (LITG, n = 24, 7 women; HITG, n = 20,
5 women) performed 5 weeks of standardized training (November)
simulating a speciﬁc preparation period with similar intensity
distribution, followed by 14 weeks of self-chosen training in the
competition period (December–March). Laboratory performance
and physiological indices in running and roller-ski skating were
determined before (PRE), after the 8-week intervention (POST-1),
and after the 5-week standardized training period (POST-2).

Roller-ski skating was also tested in the last week of the 14-
week period of self-chosen training. The complete study protocol is
displayed in Figure 1.

Participants
Forty-four (32 men and 12 women) XC skiers (8 biathletes)
participated in the study. Participant characteristics preintervention
are presented in Table 1. The Regional Committee for Medical and
Health Research Ethics waived the requirement for ethical approval
for this study. Therefore, the ethics of the study were in accordance
with the institutional requirements and approval for data security
and handling obtained from the Norwegian Centre for Research
Data. All athletes were fully informed about the nature of the study
and its experimental risks before providing a written informed
consent of their participation. The athletes were explicitly informed
that they could withdraw from the study at any point without
providing a reason for doing so. Several athletes (n = 19) were
<18 years, and therefore each of their parents was asked to provide
parental consent for their child’s participation. Three athletes in

<18 years, and therefore each of their parents was asked to provide
parental consent for their child’s participation. Three athletes in
LITG dropped out of the 5-week training period due to sickness. In
addition, 5 athletes in LITG (sickness = 3, injury = 2) and 4 athletes
in HITG (sickness = 3, injury = 1) were not able to perform the test
in the 14-week period of self-chosen training. Overall, 32 athletes
performed the last week of the 14-week period of self-chosen
training (LITG, n = 16; 6 women; HITG, n = 16; 5 women). All
athletes in the ﬁnal analyses met the criteria of 85% compliance
with the prescribed training both in the intervention and subsequent
5-week training period.

Design
After the preceding 8-week intervention,12 both groups performed a
5-week standardized training period while following similar training
regimes. The goal of this period was to simulate a speciﬁc preparation
period where we used similar training intensity distribution across
groups. This included reduced HIT duration and increased HIT
intensity, more speed training, and increased amounts of sessions
performed in competition-speciﬁc terrain. Training plans were pro-
grammed with 3 different mesocycle load structures (high, moderate,
and low), where the coaches individually selected and adjusted the
load while aiming to optimize adaptive responses for each athlete.

Accordingly, the 5-week period with similar intensity distribution led
to intensiﬁcation both in the amount of HIT sessions and by increasing
the intensity of HIT sessions for LITG, whereas HITG reduced
volume HIT but intensiﬁed the stimulus. Training characteristics
for both the 8-week intervention and subsequent 5-week period
are presented in Table 2. Typical MIT sessions were, for example,
5 × 8 minutes with 2 minutes recovery in between or 45 minutes
continuous work, whereas typical HIT sessions were, for example,
5 × 4 minutes with 2.5 minutes recovery or 7 × 3 minutes with
2-minute
recovery
periods.

Laboratory
performance
and
physiological indices in running and roller-ski skating were deter-
mined within the ﬁrst 5 days after both periods. The 14-week follow-
up period consisted of self-chosen training and competitions. While
the athletes’ training in this period was not standardized, the same
coaches programmed individual training plans and employed similar
training methods (training form and intensity) as in the 2 preceding
periods, although more on-snow ski-speciﬁc training was performed.

However, the competition schedule was highly limited by the COVID
−19 pandemic and therefore the competition period consisted mostly
of training and simulated competitions. The roller-ski skating test was
performed within the last week of the 14-week period.

Training Monitoring
All athletes recorded their own training using an online training
diary developed by the Norwegian Top Sport Centre (Olympia-
toppen) by applying the modiﬁed session-goal approach.13 All
training was systematized by training form (endurance, strength,
and speed), intensity (LIT, MIT, and HIT), and mode (speciﬁc
[roller-skiing/skiing] and nonspeciﬁc [running and cycling]). For
MIT and HIT sessions performed as intervals, time in the intensity
zone of the session was registered from the beginning of the ﬁrst
interval to the end of the last interval, including recovery periods.
Laboratory tests and competitions were also quantiﬁed as HIT.

Moreover, strength and speed training were registered from the
start to the ﬁnish of that separate part (eg, strength, speed,
plyometrics) during the session, including recovery periods.

Endurance training load using the training impulse method was
calculated by multiplying the duration in the 3 intensity zones
with a weighting factor (ie, LIT, MIT, and HIT were given a score
of 1, 2, and 3, respectively). Total training impulse was then
obtained by adding the different intensity zone scores.14,15 Heart
rate (HR) monitoring and [La−] measurements were regularly used
to ensure intensity control during both the intervention and
5-week training period.

Test Protocols and Measurements
The training plans included standardized training loads (LIT ses-
sions) over the last 2 days prior to testing. All athletes were
instructed to follow their own preparation procedures before
reporting to the laboratory on 2 separate occasions (running and
roller-ski skating) with a minimum of 24 hours in between.

Preceding both tests, a 10-minute warm-up in running was
performed (60%–72% of maximal HR). The running test consisted
of one 5-minute submaximal workload followed by an incremental
test to determine VO2max and performance measured as peak
speed (Vpeak).16 The roller-ski skating test consisted of two
5-minute submaximal workloads followed by an incremental
test to determine peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) and Vpeak.16
Roller-ski skating was performed using the G3 (V2) subtechnique.

Detailed protocols for both tests can be found elsewhere.12
Running was performed on a 2.5 × 0.7-m motor-driven
treadmill, and roller-ski skating on a 3.5- × 2.5-m treadmill
(RL 2500 and RL 3500 E; Rodby, Vänge, Sweden). Respiratory
recordings were collected between the third and fourth minute of
each submaximal workload. HR was deﬁned as the average over
the last 30 seconds. Respiratory variables were measured using
open-circuit indirect calorimetry with mixing chamber (Oxycon
Pro, Jaeger GmbH, Hoechberg, Germany) and HR measured by
use of a Garmin Forerunner 935 (Garmin Ltd, Olathe, KS).
